SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Evans for that contribution to this very important debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996. I always think, if you are going to make a second reading speech, make it brief. But I am afraid I will not hold myself to that principle in my own contribution, Madam President.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to open my remarks by saying that this bill really is the proof in the pudding of the attitude of the Howard government on the issue of migrants and migration. I think now we know why the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his government really have been so wishy‐washy in their contributions to the debate on these issues over the last few months.

This bill exposes the Howard government. The coalition could not take a strong stand on tolerance and a non‐discriminatory immigration policy when they knew that this bill was about to be debated in the Senate. The Howard government's public position is completely undermined by what they are actually proposing to do under this disgraceful piece of legislation.

Let me be absolutely clear on this. Under this proposal, people newly arrived in Australia, people who are here because they want to be here and because we want them to be here, will not enjoy the benefits of the social security safety net which is available to other Australians. Despite all the evidence which tells us that the first two years after migrating to Australia are so critical to successful settlement, the government is withdrawing the social security safety net for these people.

The two‐year waiting period will apply even to special benefit, which of course is the payment of last resort. Let me emphasise that it is the safety net which is being taken away. The majority of newly arrived residents bring resources with them or find work or are supported by their families. It is only when these alternatives fail them that they turn to the social security system.

Madam President, the government proposes through this bill to apply a two‐year waiting period for partner allowance and mature age allowance. It will apply to widows allowance and carers pension. It will apply to disability wage supplement and maternity allowance. It will apply to mobility allowance, the Commonwealth seniors card and the health care card. These are all payments which, until now, have been paid with no waiting period.

Family payment will only be paid at the minimum rate of $22.70 per child per fortnight when previously higher rates of family payment have been available to low income families with children in Australia. Many of these people are taxpayers, people who have come here to make their home and who are earning an income.

PARA.BREAK: We have reason to believe that it is not going to stop here. The budget announced that the two‐year waiting period would apply to Austudy. The budget announced that effectively the two‐year waiting period will apply to what is left of the labour market programs. On the original list of legislation that was going to be dealt with in this session of parliament, we had a bill which would have applied the two‐year waiting period to the child‐care cash rebate—money to partly reim burse working people who pay taxes for the costs of their child care.

SPEECH.PARA: The people we welcome as new Australians need to draw on the support of their families and friends, their communities and their government at this critical time. Now, their government is telling them that they are effectively on their own, that the government washes its hands of its responsibilities to provide assistance to these people when it is so desperately needed.

The Howard government is creating an Australia with two classes of people. One class, arriving in Australia more than two years ago, is allowed to enjoy the benefits of our community commitment and obligation to protect those who are in need, the manifestation of our commitment to protect those who are most vulnerable. They can enjoy access to health services, to education, to social security payments—effectively the building blocks of our social safety net. These people might be low income workers with children, who can get the extra help that they need, when they need it.

Through this bill the government is creating second‐class Australians—people during the first two years after their arrival in Australia who, even though they may be in an identical situation to their neighbours—live in the same street, send their kids to the same school, work for the same company—do not have the security of the same safety net. They may be low income workers with children but too bad, the Howard government is not going to help them in any way.

It would be useful in this second reading debate to remind the Senate how this fiasco has been played out between February this year and now. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, when he was Leader of the Opposition, set out a number of key principles prior to the last election. Included in his approach towards the area of immigration was a commitment to principles of multiculturalism and non‐discriminatory practices and outcomes. In his speech to ACOSS he committed himself to an approach which would protect those who were least well off and most vulnerable in our society. He said:

BREAK.PARA: One of the main reasons why Australia continues to be such an attractive proposition for prospective migrants is that, over an extended period of time, we have built an enviable reputation as a tolerant and compassionate society. Notwithstanding this fact, it remains a reality that many Australians from non‐English speaking backgrounds have considerable difficulty grasping the opportunities and accessing the services that are often taken for granted by those in the wider community. . . We have a duty to ensure that newly arrived migrants are able to acquire the language and vocational skills needed to participate fully in the labour market.
On 16 February, Mr Howard gave his personal pledge to those who were concerned about the imposition of a two‐year waiting period for newly arrived residents. In a doorstop interview, he said:

Can I make it clear. . . Take the migrant waiting periods. . . it doesn't apply to refugees, it doesn't apply in humanitarian circumstances. . . It, of course, doesn't apply to family allowance and other benefits.
But after the election we discovered that the Prime Minister had written to Senator Vanstone on 13 May, saying:
I am writing in regard to the Government's introduction of a two year waiting period before migrants can access a range of social security and other payments.

As you will recall, Cabinet decided on March 27 1996. . . that this two year waiting period would be extended to a range of payments beyond those proposed in Senator Newman's original submission. In particular, cabinet decided that you should review and report back on the eligibility criteria for labour market programs and access to AUSTUDY.

The list of additional social security payments to which the waiting period will apply has now been finalised. I therefore wish also to finalise the status of labour market programs and AUSTUDY. Accordingly, I would be grateful if you would provide immediately for Cabinet's consideration a submission on changes to extend the waiting period to these programs.
The Prime Minister also wrote to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. In that letter, the Prime Minister—very well‐mannered—said:
Thank you for your letter of 30 April 1996 regarding the additional payments to be included on the two year waiting period list for migrants.
I agree to your proposal that the Commonwealth Seniors Health Card and Disadvantaged Persons Scheme Health Care Cards be included on the waiting period list.
I support your proposal to include special benefit on the waiting period list, with an exemption for the safety net arrangements. I also support the draft revised guidelines for special benefit.

With regard to child disability allowance, double orphan pension, disability wage supplement and mobility allowance, I propose that the waiting period will apply, unless the migrant becomes eligible after his or her arrival in Australia.

Notwithstanding your concerns about Childcare Assistance and Childcare Cash Rebate, and your desire to consult with the Minister for Health and Family Services, I propose that the two year waiting period apply to these payments. In addition to the payments considered above, I propose that the Maximum Family Payment (formerly Additional Family Payment), Maternity Allowance and Multiple Birth Allowance be included on the waiting period list.
Even after these letters, the Prime Minister said in the House of Representatives on 22 May:
Can I just make it perfectly clear to the Leader of the Opposition . . . You introduced a six-month period. All we have done is to extend your six months to two years.

We accept that there is on this issue an authority from the election to extend what is currently a six-month waiting period for newstart, sickness, parenting and youth training allowance to a two-year waiting period. But it is for these changes alone. As Senator Bolkus indicated a little earlier in this second reading debate, the opposition will be moving substantial amendments to this bill in the committee stage.

The government says that all they are doing is extending a principle that was introduced by the former Labor government. So I think it is important, given that claim, to look at some of the history. In 1993, the then government did introduce a six-month waiting period for new arrivals in this country to ensure that those new arrivals and their sponsors did meet some of the incidental costs of their initial settlement. The six-month period was selected as a balance.

We had to meet our responsibilities as an Australian community to welcome and accept those who were here to become our new citizens—to provide for them a range of universal benefits through the health system, through educational opportunities and through welfare benefits. We had to provide for them a network of access and equity opportunities and training in skills that are necessary for them to be able to take advantage of their new residency in this country in, for example, language training. We put on one side our responsibility for these universal approaches and we put on the other side the responsibility for those who sponsor new arrivals to meet the costs that are incidental to that new settlement. Six months, we believe, was an appropriate balancing point.

Now, with the introduction of this bill, our `enviable reputation as a tolerant and compassionate society' is under threat—not only from this legislation but also from other legislation which will follow it. It is legislation which will, for example, cut rent assistance for single people sharing accommodation by a third, deny unemployment payments to people for up to six months and make it much more difficult to qualify for a disability support pension.

So much for the Howard government's commitment to protect the poor, the needy and the most vulnerable in our community. What is absolutely clear from this legislation is that this government is trying to withdraw the safety net for newly arrived residents who find themselves, unexpectedly, poor, needy or vulnerable.

I believe the government stands exposed on its duplicity on this particular issue and stands condemned for the breaches of commitments that it made before the election—the commitments, of course, that were not honoured by the newly elected coalition government. I commend to the Senate the amendments that will be moved by Senator Bolkus in the committee stage of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contributions in this debate. It has been an important and far-reaching one. It is unfortunate that some of the Labor speakers have chosen to make comments that I think have gone wide of the mark of the intent of the legislation. They have introduced into this debate unnecessary comments that have sought to elevate and exacerbate the issues of the current debate on racist and racial issues in the community—both at this time and, in particular, with regard to this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 gives effect to the government's election commitment to introduce a two-year waiting period for newly arrived residents. It continues to grant all eligible refugee and humanitarian migrants access to welfare benefits immediately on their arrival in Australia—contrary to the view of some members and what they have been saying.

The bill provides access to welfare benefits for other migrants, which will be available after two years. It grants full access to the family allowance—now called the minimum family payment—and Medicare for all migrants immediately on arrival. It provides a safety net for those migrants whose circumstances change significantly upon arrival in Australia for reasons beyond their personal control.

The policy will apply to prospective migrants only. It will not apply retrospectively or to migrants who arrived in Australia before 1 April 1996. This represents the election commitment announced in February by the now Treasurer (Mr Costello)—no more, no less. The government took this policy to the election, and it has a mandate to introduce it. This commitment reinforces the government's position that new migrants should not be expected to rely on taxpayers as soon as they arrive in Australia and that sponsors of new migrants will honour their obligations to provide the support they promised when migrants applied for their visas.

The government has moved a range of amendments as a result of the report from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. I would commend many of the comments made yesterday by Senator Ellison, Senator Abetz, Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan from that committee. The committee took evidence from a wide variety of community groups and representatives. The government has listened to those concerns and has moved amendments that give effect to all the legislative recommendations of the majority report. It picks up a number of consistent recommendations also from the minority report.

The amendment means that no waiting period will be applied to child disability allowance or double orphan pension. Special need relatives—that is, those who migrate to provide care for Australian residents—will not have to wait for access to a carer pension. Australian citizens' children born overseas will not have to wait for above minimum rate family payments. Innocent illegals will not serve the waiting period for any payments, and interdependency migrants—these are subclass 826—will not have to serve a waiting period when they are granted permanent residence. The original bill also includes this exemption for those granted temporary spouse visas.

The government, unlike the Australian Labor Party, has listened. The Labor Party is being selective in what it wants to hear and then raise in this place. Senator Bolkus's comments yesterday very much went to that particular point, almost seeking to raise and to make a new agenda. The committee majority has reported that the bill does not apply retrospectively. The committee majority also concluded that this bill does not offend the Racial Discrimination Act nor does it breach international agreements, contrary to the comments of some of the speakers yesterday.

The Australian Labor Party call for a review prior to the implementation of this policy. The former Labor government had no such review prior to introducing the 26-week waiting period, nor did they take this policy to the electorate. They announced it in a budget speech and implemented it some four months later. The Democrats have raised the issue of refugees and humanitarian migrants.

I am disappointed that Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Woodley obviously have not read the detail of the majority report. This bill does not limit in any way this group's access to social security payments. In fact, the government is extending the exemption to take in their family members who migrate to Australia even if this is some time later. This new exemption, which does not apply under the 26-week waiting period, will assist the family reunion of the most disadvantaged migrants—that is, refugees.

Calls for a tax exemption for new migrants who do not access social security is not relevant. This measure is introduced to ensure that sponsors and assurers of new migrants meet their commitments. This measure will bring the Australian social security system closer into line with social security arrangements in other countries which require an employment and contribution history before people access entitlements. New migrants can still access a vast array of government services, including Medicare, education and infrastructure.

Many of the speakers have said that new migrants will be left without any assistance for two years. This is not true. Special benefit—the safety net—will always be available to those new migrants who need assistance because their circumstances have changed since their arrival in Australia. We have made it clear that this safety net would be maintained; however, we have also said that new migrants and/or their sponsors would be required to meet their own obligations first. Medicare and the minimum rate family payment will also continue to be available to new residents.

Senator McKiernan raised the issue of the level of savings from this bill as compared with the estimates during the election campaign. The savings we present with this bill are based on actual social security data—something we did not have access to whilst in opposition. The savings are conservative Department of Finance estimates, which are agreed by Finance.

The Australian Labor Party in proposing that it is prepared to support a two-year waiting period for those payments that already have a 26-week waiting period fails to acknowledge a number of issues. Widow allowance currently has a 26-week residence requirement—in effect, a 26-week waiting period. The social security system is now one based on individual entitlement: each person qualifies in their own right for payment and not on the basis of their spouse's entitlements. This change was begun by the previous government and we are continuing that policy direction.

The parenting allowance has a 26-week waiting period but partner allowance does not—again, inconsistent with individual entitlement. Not applying a waiting period to special benefit, albeit with exemptions for people who have a change of circumstances, will allow people to effectively bypass the waiting period and allow migrants and their sponsors to continue to avoid their responsibilities.

It is interesting that a number of speakers yesterday were very sympathetic and empathetic—indicative of the natural sympathy and empathy that we all have for people in new circumstances fitting in with a new community. I was personally very surprised by Senator Woodley's comments. He obviously repeated his sermon from the day before. He drew allowance and took us back to the days of Abraham. I do not want to exchange the social security arrangements of Australia for those of some 3,000 years ago. I do not think they would be appropriate, and I think Senator Woodley missed the mark very seriously in those areas with regard to what is community support and community obligation.

This is good policy. It certainly will pick up a number of very important issues. This bill puts in place a government election commitment. The government has also put forward a range of amendments. We have listened to community concerns, we have responded and we have taken note of the report of the Senate committee, but we have not moved so far away as to send the message that new migrants and their sponsors can forget their commitments and ignore their responsibilities.

It should be noted that this is also in accordance with the recommendations of the House of Representatives committee which considered the application of section 53. The Australian Democrats voiced our opposition and concern about the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill yesterday in the speeches made Senator Woodley and me. We have just expressed our opposition to this bill in the vote.

I strongly support the words of Senator Faulkner earlier today in this debate when he said that the motivations behind this bill should be exposed. We maintain that we should not merely expose the content of this bill but also seek to oppose it. That is what the Australian Democrats' amendments before the chamber today provide the opportunity to do—certainly for the opposition and other parties in this place.

The first two amendments, which in some respects are consequential on amendments Nos 3 to 21 being passed, simply address the Australian Democrats' opposition to this bill in total and cut to the heart of this bill and our concerns. Amendments Nos 3 to 21 regard the specific pensions, entitlements or social security benefits to which the extension of the waiting period is to be applied. Again, they seek to oppose the extension of the waiting period from six months to two years. Included in those amendments, I understand that there are certain government amendments in light of the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. There are some amendments to be moved by the government today which will take up some of the concerns that were previously raised in the Australian Democrats' amendments.

I wish to briefly refer to some of the entitlements that will be affected by this legislation and the extension of the waiting period. They include the carers pension. Amendment No. 4 of the Australian Democrats deals with this. It is important for people to remember that the carers pension exists to ensure an adequate level of income for a person who provides full‐time personal care to a severely disabled person. This type of assurance of support is already catered for in the migration regulations. I ask the committee to consider this, because who is it that primarily is responsible for taking care of such people? I would argue that the majority of carers in our society are women. This extension of the waiting period is a thinly veiled attack on carers, particularly on migrant women.

Amendment No. 6 of the Australian Democrats relates to the disability wage supplement. This provides a supplement to those people with a disability working under the supported wages system administered by the Department of Health and Family Services. Again, who are the primary carers of such severely disabled people in our society? Women. So again I consider the attack on the disability wage supplement an attack on women, particularly migrant women, in our society.

I know Senator Woodley is particularly concerned about the widow allowance, which is addressed in Democrat amendment No. 5. The widow allowance is designed to allow an adequate level of income for women who have been widowed, separated or divorced after turning 50 years of age and who have no recent work force experience. Again this is an attack on migrant women.

PARA.BREAK: Amendment No. 10 deals with the sickness allowance. The sickness allowance is provided to people who are employed and who have lost income due to a temporary incapacity caused by sickness or injury. Because of the relative position of financial inequality, it is women who are more likely to require such allowances as their income usually is prohibi tive of purchasing private insurance. Again this is an attack on women, particularly migrant women.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Democrat amendment No. 11 deals with the special benefit. The special benefit provides assistance to people in severe financial need due to circumstances that are outside their control and for whom no other allowances are payable and no other support is available. Clearly, this is a benefit of last resort. As the Lavarch committee report illustrated, it is women who are most clearly disadvantaged following divorce proceedings. Therefore, an attack on the special benefit is again another thinly veiled attack on migrant women in our community.

Our amendment No. 12 deals with the partner allowance. The partner allowance provides for partners of income support recipients who face barriers to finding employment because of their limited participation in the work force. Whom is this largely going to impact upon? Again migrant women. For that reason we oppose the extension of the waiting period to the partner allowance.

Amendment No. 13 deals with the maternity allowance. Amendment No. 14 deals with the parenting allowance, which provides financial assistance to families where a partner cares for children at home. Again it is largely women who are in that position. Obviously, the maternity allowance affects women and, in this case, migrant women in particular.

We have an amendment dealing with the mobility allowance. We oppose the extension of the waiting period to the mobility allowance. The mobility allowance provides assistance to people with disabilities in employment, vocational training or voluntary work who are unable to use public transport without substantial assistance.

Other rafts of measures are affected by this bill, such as the youth training allowance and newstart. As I understand it, the government amendments will pick up the child disability allowance and the double orphan pension—something we do support.

I reiterate the Democrats' concerns. We see this legislation as mean spirited. We see it as penny pinching and as a way of revenue raising from migrants in this country. I think it clearly sends our community and those people overseas who are going to join us the wrong message.

Beyond that, when we hold this piece of legislation up to the light of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, it is dubious legally. It is a questionable piece of legislation. Yesterday the Democrats put on record our concerns about the continued stratification in our society—the idea that we should be treating citizens and permanent residents so differently.

So there are legal concerns, ethical concerns and racial concerns that the Australian Democrats have with this bill. Again I concur with the sentiments of Senator Faulkner earlier today where he said, `This is an attempt to withdraw the safety net from the poor, the needy and the vulnerable'—those were his words. He argued that we should expose the duplicity in the government's case.

—As I said yesterday, the opposition has very deep problems with the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996. These problems arise from the fact that this legislation does not in any way pay adequate respect to the traditional role that settlement programs have played in Australia's migration program.

BREAK.PARA: As I said yesterday, when President Clinton and other world leaders recognise that we have been a successful migration country not only do they look at the numbers that we take—in fact, there was no reference last week by President Clinton to the fact that we have taken some 5.3 million migrants in some 50 years since the war in a planned migration program—but they also look at the way those migrants settle into the Australian community.

Settlement programs are critical. We have maintained that settlement programs provide not only an investment in those who migrate here but also an investment for the cohesive nature of our society. We find it is important that we do have programs such as the ones we are discussing today—labour market programs, English language programs as well as the settlement programs that are provided directly to migrants through community groups and broader based organisations.

All these programs are the investment that the Australian public puts into migration, an investment which provides a springboard for migrants when they come here. The migration experience is not easy. It is very difficult. We have been successful because we have been able to ensure that migrants do not fall through the floor and become an underclass.

We do have a very high mobility rate no matter what the migrant group that comes to Australia is and no matter whom the migrant's family is. Mobility is something which is a very deep characteristic of the way that migrants have settled into Australian society—mobility in terms of where they live, mobility in terms of where they study and mobility in terms of where they are employed. That is why, no matter where you go throughout the Australian landscape, you will find the rich diversity of migration reflected in the shops, in the religious institutions and in just about every suburb in this country.

Settlement programs in the social justice agenda are critical. It is for that reason that the previous government for 13 years consistently built on that agenda. For instance, it spent more money on language programs over the last few years and more money on settlement programs. It recognised the need and the services provided by migrant resource centres, aid workers and the like and the need for labour market programs to address the particular problems that migrants face when they are trying to get into the work force.

We also struck a balance, and that balance is reflected in our opposition to these amendments moved by the Australian Democrats today. The balance was between on the one hand making that investment, ensuring that investment could provide a safety net for migrants, and on the other hand ensuring that those who do migrate and those who sponsor new arrivals do meet some of the incidental costs of that new settlement.

That is why we struck the six‐month period. We struck it as a balancing point, but we struck it only in respect of some and not the whole raft of programs. When people compare our position with the current position, they will find that we were selective about the programs that we apply the six‐month waiting period to, and our waiting period had nowhere near the impact that the government's amendments to the legislation are having to the programs. We thought six months was an appropriate period. A period of two years will ensure an undermining of the cohesiveness of this society.

As I said yesterday, it is not migration programs that cause ghettos. It is the economic programs, it is the lack or provision of social service programs and social justice programs which have an impact on whether people are mobile in the new community in which they settle.

We oppose the amendments of the Democrats because they do try to wind back that balancing point of six months. We also oppose them because we feel that the government has some authority in respect of extending that six‐month waiting period but only in those areas in which they made it clear before the election that they would so move. The government made it clear that they would extend our six‐month period to two years only in those areas where that six‐month period applied.

No degree of dissembling by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) or by the relevant ministers—I do not include Senator Tambling here because he has not had carriage of this in the past—whether it is Senator Newman or Senator Vanstone or any other minister, will interpret the words and the commitment before the election to mean the inclusion of the wide raft of amendments that the government is seeking to implement now. We will allow the government's pre‐election commitment to take effect here. We will not allow it to be extended to the raft of programs that the Australian public was not warned about, nor will we allow it to extend the period to two years in those programs.

Unfortunately, Senator Stott Despoja, we share very much your concerns with this legislation, but we feel that the balance we struck before the election can be maintained. It is a balance that was working because of a specific government commitment before the election to ensure that there were allowances for the hard cases. We were consistent in our application of special benefit provisions before the election and this government has sought to apply separate benchmarks for special benefits since the election. Before the election we were also very keen to ensure that there was sufficient top‐up in those programs that were critical to ensuring either enhanced access to language skills or labour market programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor opposition says that it struck the balance with the six‐month waiting period but immediately catches itself in the impossible position of arguing against extending that to two years, 10 years or 20 years, or maybe a lifetime coming further down the line if we extend the illogicality which says that people who are legitimate migrants to Australia and have been through the trial of assessment before they get here should be second‐class citizens once they arrive for however long the period is.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor may say it is six months. The coalition says, `Let's make it two years.' The fact is that the major parties are institutionalising discrimination against newly arrived Australians at the very time they will most need assistance and at the very time the social security network is most important to ensure that they find their legs, that they have the best opportunity possible of integrating into the Australian society, that they have the best opportunity possible to find work and fulfilment, to get income, to be able to settle in to this new country and to become the productive citizens that they want to be.

`Well,' says Labor, `let's put a six‐month'—and they have managed to do this—`waiting period on the people from the minute they step ashore.' `Oh,' say the Liberal and National parties, `we will now make it two years.' Where do you put an end to this drift to discrimination in this country of an unfair go?

I reiterate that this law being put to the chamber today breaks international covenants on civil rights. It breaks a series of international covenants which say that all citizens should be treated equally and all citizens should have an equal access to social security in whatever country they might be. But here we have Australia saying, through this government legislation, `Not quite. We are going to discriminate against you from the minute you get here. We are going to make it tough on you for the coming two years.'

As Senator Stott Despoja pointed out, if you happen to become a widow during those two years, extra tough luck, you do not have access to the benefits, meagre as they might be, to help you get by while you settle to that loss and find some means of income. You will have to find it somewhere else. Do not look to the Australian government as all other Australian citizens in that position can do. Because you are new in this country, you don't get a fair go. That is what this legislation says. It is an unfair go if you happen to be a newly arrived Australian. Sure, we welcome you, but we are not going to give you a fair go.

It is ethically wrong that the chamber should pass this legislation. That is why the Greens support the Democrat amendments, not only because they stop this rot going further—they stop the added discrimination that is inherent in this government legislation now before the chamber—but because the Democrat amendments along with Green sentiment try to roll back the injustice that was built into this line of government direction when the Labor Party in government two years ago said a six‐month penalty should be applied to newcomers to this country.

I remind the committee that, at any given time, 8,000 to 10,000 people in Australia will suffer the denial of potential benefits which other ordinary Australians have available to them if the amendments which we support are knocked back, as it seems they will be, by a Senate majority. I join the Democrats in saying to the Labor Party, the party of social justice: think again about this; you made the mistake in government. Do not compound it by turning down the opportunity to endorse these amendments now. It is simply an appeal for a fair go for people newly arrived in this country to take up their new role in life, their new opportunities in life and their new avenues to fulfilment as Australians—no more and no less than the rest of us.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) To avoid doubt, any provision in this Act imposing a waiting period does not apply to:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) For the purposes of subsection (1), family member has the same meaning as in subsection 7(6D) of the Social Security Act 1991.

We have moved this amendment to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 because we are concerned that nothing in this legislation says that the waiting period will not apply to either a refugee or humanitarian migrant, their family members, Australian citizens or their family members. There is concern that this legislation will have a discriminatory impact against Australian citizens or—as will be reflected in our next amendment in respect of the Racial Discrimination Act—between Australians.

That concern was picked up by the Race Discrimination Commissioner, Ms Zita Antonios, in evidence to the committee. She was not the only person who raised this particular concern before the committee. She expressed her concerns as follows:

. . . as the Race Discrimination Commissioner I say that the perception could easily be that the proposed bill is inconsistent with the standards and the spirit that is embodied in the Racial Discrimination Act. I do not say that that is intentional; I think it is an unintentional consequence of Australia's agreements with countries like New Zealand and, in a limited circumstance, the United Kingdom. That is the key point I wish to stress . . .

Together with that concern about discrimination on the basis of race, we are particularly concerned that no Australian citizen or their family will be affected by this legislation in a discriminatory way. For instance, we do not want families of Australian citizens to be denied any access to benefits which they would have been receiving before this legislation. That is why we have the subclauses in 2A to protect the rights of Australian citizens or their families.

We are also particularly concerned that this legislation may have a harsh impact on refugees or humanitarian entrants to Australia. We have once again in this area had a proud record in terms of the numbers of people in humanitarian circumstances which we have taken into Australia. Some half a million Australian citizens have come in as refugees and humanitarian entrants over the last 40 to 50 years. They have come in from all parts of the world. They have come in suffering from all sorts of duress and repression, physical or mental. The government needs to ensure that we respond to them and their needs when they come into our country.

We should once again acknowledge that where we have provided resources and benefits here—and both sides of parliament have done so consistently over the years—those resources have had a very positive impact on the people that they have been applied to and people who have been the beneficiaries of them. As a consequence, you find many people in our society, who have come here as refugees or humanitarian entrants, who are making a very positive contribution.

I keep on referring to the situation of the Vietnamese community—a community which is sometimes criticised in our popular media but which, despite some high levels of job seeking and dependence on social security benefits, has achieved enormously both in the workplace and in educational institutions. This community has been with us only for 20 years as a migrant group. There were a small number of Vietnamese Australians before the end of the Indochina war. In 20 years, people who have come here substantially as refugees and humanitarian entrants have made a very strong contribution. Their retention rates at schools are some 10 per cent above the rest of Australia. Their detention rate in prisons is below the rest of Australia. Their participation—particularly by women—in the workplace is higher than the Australian norm. They are one group.

The Cambodians are another group. The Cambodians who had to suffer the repression and oppression of Pol Pot are enormously mobile in our society. They do rely on that assistance we give them in the first instance to give them a springboard in establishing their new lives. I could go across the world. People coming in from the Middle East or the former Yugoslavia, from East Timor, from Sri Lanka and the like have made an enormously good fist of their lives here and they have relied on access to social benefits to get them a bit of a start‐off. The government and the Australian public get paid back from day one just about, because all these people have to go out shopping, they do need food, they do need whitegoods and so on. In purchasing those, they immediately pay back into government coffers through the whole raft of indirect taxes that they have to meet.

Look, for instance, at their employment rate. Some 75 per cent of them are in the work force within 18 months to two years of their arriving here. They are the people who could otherwise be disadvantaged if we do not protect them through a provision like this.

I accept from the government that there is some concern that the amendment as it now stands may need a bit of an addition to ensure it has the impact that we from this side of parliament desire it to have. For that reason I have moved amendment No. 1 in its amended form.
I indicate at this stage that we anticipate an amendment from Senator Harradine to our amendment here, and the opposition is keen and willing to accept that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coonan for the question. ANSWER.PARA: There is no escaping the fact that the expenditure of that money has failed to achieve any improvement in the area of indigenous deaths in custody. We regarded this problem as a matter of urgency, but we also recognise that consultation with and involvement of indigenous people is essential. Eight indigenous consultation sessions have been scheduled between 11 November and 18 December in all states and meetings have already occurred in Adelaide and Alice Springs. These sessions involve concerned indigenous organisations and the state police and corrective services departments.

The extensive process of consultation with indigenous communities will be followed by a national summit of indigenous representatives on 17 and 18 February to set the direction of the ministerial summit six weeks later. Commonwealth, state and territory ministers with responsibilities for indigenous affairs, law and justice, policing and corrective services, and juvenile justice have been invited to attend the summit.
