The research shows that middle Australia has been hard hit by falling real wages and the thinning of jobs—Labor's legacy. In particular, what has Labor done in relation to middle income families? Young middle income families are the first generation since World War II whose living standards have not risen during a period of economic recovery. Employment in the middle income earning range for male full‐time workers fell significantly under Labor. Household incomes below $44,000 fell in real terms. The proportion of people falling to the bottom of the income earnings ladder almost doubled over a 15‐year period, while the number who moved to the top has doubled.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last statement is not true.
—There is a greater gap between the rich and poor, Senator Cook. That is your legacy—more poor, more rich. What a boast. Middle Australia missed out again.

ANSWER.PARA: That reminds me of what I have said before in the Senate. Middle income earners saw their real household incomes fall by nearly $58 per week in Labor's first 10 years of office, Senator Cook. Home loan repayments were 19 per cent of median family income in 1983. Under Labor, they rose to a massive 27 per cent. I also remind honourable senators that it was Labor that gave us nearly one million unemployed, the highest rates of unemployment since the 1930s. Labor left 27 per cent of young Australians out of work when it was thrown out of office.

This is the legacy of Labor, the party that claims to be the party of social justice. This report today reaffirms what all Australian voters knew when they went to the polls in March. That is why Labor was so unceremoniously thrown out of office. That is reinforced by what Labor knows internally. I remind honourable senators of what former Labor Senator Graham Richardson said recently:
The electorate doesn't want to have anything to do with them or their party. The electorate has neither forgiven nor forgotten.
This is reinforced by former Labor premiers coming out and saying, `Labor people used to know instinctively what was the Labor theme, now they are no longer sure what it means.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this make you feel good?

—No, I think you need to reflect on your failure before you start to improve, Senator Bolkus. That is the point. When you learn the lesson, you will sit back and start to develop some worthwhile policies and be a constructive and useful opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The contrast is the Howard coalition government. What are we giving middle Australians? We are giving them greater hope for the future. We have already been able to introduce the $1 billion family tax initiative, which will benefit some two million eligible families; 80 per cent of all families with children will benefit from this initiative from January next year.

Under the Howard government, middle income earners are now getting mortgage relief—$145 a month for an average $100,000 loan. Interest rates are down to around eight per cent as opposed to 17 per cent under Labor. Middle income earners will have noted the strong investment figures for September, which give them greater hope of an improving economy with benefits that will flow down to them.
So under the coalition government, by contrast, all the signs are for hope and opportunity—lower interest rates, lower inflation, lower taxes and a good future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of the scathing attack on the government by the Premier of Western Australia on the issue of your proposal to restrict the number of doctors entering general practice? Is it true that Mr Court has stated that the restrictions on new doctors will affect Western Australia's ability to fill shortages, particularly in rural areas and some medical specialities? Is it also true that he has expressed concern that actions taken to address an oversupply problem elsewhere will create or exacerbate problems in the supply of doctors in Western Australia? Will the government try to accommodate Premier Court's concerns or does the government regard them as special pleading related to the upcoming election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Nice try, Senator. The situation, as I am advised by the Minister for Health and Family Services, is that Western Australia is not short of doctors compared with the national average.
—So Court is a liar, is he?
—The Premier may not be aware of the figures, Senator. I am advised by the health minister that the availability of doctors in the west is marginally higher than the national average.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections. Persistent interjections are disorderly.

—I do not know that there is a great deal more to add to the answer that the senator wants because his question is obviously based on a false premise. Nevertheless, if there are more particulars, I will be happy to get them from the health minister.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation is, as I said yesterday, that there is a great deal of misinformation about the changes to the provider numbers. There are a great deal of opportunities for young doctors to be employed on a salary basis without the need for provider numbers. I point out that the defence forces, for example, are short of doctors, as Senator Ray would know only too well. The Australian Government Health Service is short of salaried doctors. There are something like 400 positions around Australia in the public hospitals where salaried doctors are badly needed.

So the proposals of the Australian government requiring young graduates to have additional training before they become general practitioners with a right to have a provider number are not unfair. They are reasonable. As I said yesterday, we want a quality of care for our patients which can be evidenced by sufficient training. I remember that Jenny Macklin, for instance, had a national health strategy for the previous government in which improving the training of our doctors was given a very high priority.

The situation is that we are focusing on the improved training of general practitioners, but they are not precluded in any way from getting an income—a very substantial income, as I understand it—from those sources that I referred to earlier. The initial question, as I say, is based on a false premise. If there is anything that I can add to that, I will get it from the health minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, is it not true that the attitude of this government so far has been, `It is okay to have environment laws as long as they do not get in the way of business'? Have we not seen big business win on cabling over planning, on mining over native title, on coal over greenhouse, on woodchips over forests and on uranium over national parks—the list is already long? Will not this negative trend be exacerbated by your announcement today that you intend to `streamline environmental laws' substantially in favour of business? I ask this because it appears that, under your plans, ultimate control of federal environmental decisions will in future be at the discretion of either the states or the entire federal cabinet, not you alone. Is it not true that the only time you will get to make a decision on environmental matters is when it is simply rubber stamping?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot is wrong again, I regret to say. She has got it totally wrong. What she is really witnessing from this government may be a little less theatre but a little more substance. The environment is, in fact, the winner.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment, the reforms we are looking at are long overdue and will lead to environmental benefit. The problem is that you have got it so wrong, because at the moment it is the environment minister that does not have any real powers under the Commonwealth environmental structures. You should know by now that all the environment minister can do is make recommendations. Often he or she does not even get the opportunity to do that because major environmental issues are not triggered under the existing Commonwealth legislation. It is these shortcomings—it is no good looking at the article in the newspaper, Senator—that we are seeking to overcome. We are saying that the Commonwealth should be concentrating on issues of national environmental importance and that that should be the trigger, not whether there is a FIRB application or an export permit in question—matters that are really irrelevant to the question as to whether there is an environmental issue that should be looked at. The test should be whether there is an issue of national environmental importance, in which case there should then be a responsibility on the Commonwealth to conduct whatever assessment is necessary and then, hopefully, have the powers to implement a decision, which it does not have at the moment. I will give you a couple of examples that might help. Take the one of Hinchinbrook that you have mentioned on many occasions: if the test was national environmental significance, then Senator Faulkner, when minister, would have been able to call for an environmental impact study into that proposal. He was not able to because of the inadequacies of the Commonwealth legislation.

One in your home state recently—the proposed cotton farming on the Cooper—could have an effect not only on my state but on internationally listed wetlands. At the moment it does not fall within a trigger. There is no opportunity—

TALK.START.PARA: —We fixed that one.
—You have upset the National Party. Ron is not too happy with that one.
—I am pleased to see the state—
—We fixed it.
—I don't whether you have fixed it, but anyway. I wish Senator Boswell would let me answer Senator Kernot's important question on an important issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I was giving you the cotton example. Ramsar listed wetlands in the centre of Australia could have been affected by that development, but there was no capacity for the Commonwealth minister to require an environmental impact study.

TALK.START.PARA: —The way Hill is going you will be environment minister, Boz.

—Don't interrupt! If the test had been of national environmental significance, then because of the Ramsar listing and the commitments we had made under the international convention, we would have had the capacity to conduct that inquiry.

BREAK.PARA: These reforms are not a handover of powers to the states. They are an attempt to try to appreciate what are Commonwealth responsibilities and state responsibilities and, in relation to the Commonwealth, to give it the task of carrying out a proper assessment process and then taking what action is necessary to protect national environmental interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I think you are wrong in saying you do not have any power now. You do have power under world heritage legislation. The point of my question was simply that you have listed criteria under which projects will be considered to have national environmental significance. But you have also said that, where there is a chance a project will be blocked, the decision will go to the full cabinet. Doesn't that mean that other ministers will have more power over controversial environmental decisions than you will have? You will be able to use cabinet secrecy to avoid giving an explanation for controversial decisions. Isn't that clearly very convenient and a retrograde step?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Senator Kernot has got it wrong yet again.
—No, I haven't. You weren't answering the question.

—You see, under the EPIP Act, my only power is to make a recommendation. So I make a recommendation to Senator Parer, who then decides whether to allow it or not. I find this astonishing because I would expect you to be in here calling for a broadening of that responsibility rather than dwelling on the past. You are seeking to argue that it is an environment minister that should have some powers in this regard rather than what is the case at present.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kernot, I regret to say that you have misinterpreted the law and, as a result of that, you have misjudged what we are seeking to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, what you would like us to do is more akin to what is going to occur if this negotiation finally comes to a positive conclusion.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Question time is not a time for the questioner and answerer to continually spar across the chamber.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, is it a fact that a law reform researcher with the Federation of Community Legal Centres, Ms Liz Curran, has stated that the withdrawal of funding for domestic violence orders, occurring as a consequence of the federal government's cuts to legal aid, would put at risk the lives of women and children who face delays while waiting for such orders? Is it a fact that the Chairman of the Australian Legal Assistance Board, Mr John King, in a letter to legal aid commissioners stated that such allegations were easily made and often done only to get grants of aid? Do you agree with Mr King's comments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the comments that Senator McKiernan quoted from and I do not know the context in which they were made. Nevertheless, I would draw to the Senate's attention the arrangements which are sought to be put into place by the Commonwealth in regard to legal aid. Despite some people's claims to the contrary, they are not gender specific or gender discriminatory.

ANSWER.PARA: Legal aid is very much being refocused so that the Commonwealth provides the legal aid for Commonwealth legislation for which it is responsible and the states are asked to provide legal aid for legislation for which they are responsible. It seems to me a pretty reasonable way to determine state and Commonwealth responsibilities. Sometimes, in all these cases, we hear claims that are not borne out in fact. I really would have liked the opportunity to have had an examination of the claims that have been made that you quoted, Senator. I am not able to comment on them till I see—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know that domestic violence orders are under state legislation? Therefore, you are saying you won't fund them.
—Order!

—You do have someone rabbiting on in front of you. It is a little hard to see what you are saying. I would be very happy to get further information based on an examination of the quotes that you have made.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I thank you for that answer, Minister. I really am surprised that, as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, you were not aware of those comments that were made way back in September. I thank you for your offer to get further information and bring it back to me. I ask also: is the minister aware that the Minister for Health and Family Services will be presenting the 1996 Australian Violence Prevention Awards on 4 December? Can you explain whether this event will proceed, given the federal government's neglect of programs which genuinely reduce the threat to families confronted with violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have possession of Minister Moylan's diary, but I will get an answer for you on her commitments. Nevertheless, when it comes to domestic violence, you should be aware of the fact that a couple of months ago the Office of the Status of Women ran a very valuable two-day forum in which experts from all Australian states took part. I think there were something like five experts from every state. In addition, representatives from non-government organisations all around Australia also took part.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that domestic violence forum, a number of principles have been drawn together by the Office of the Status of Women, and they are currently being prepared for distribution to the state governments. It is planned that next year the premiers and the Prime Minister will meet together to see what we can cooperatively do to lessen the incidence of domestic violence in Australia. These are important measures; they are not political games. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environ ment. I refer to the selectively leaked reports in the media this morning about the cabinet decision to revamp environmental laws in this country. I ask: by what mechanism will issues of national environmental or economic significance be judged? Will you be using the corporations power? Will there be any public referral process on ministerial determinations on issues of national significance? Under this new regime who will be responsible for ensuring that states meet national and internationally agreed standards on the environment where projects are not deemed to be of national economic or environmental significance, particularly given that states such as WA are eroding environmental standards and accountability in a push to attract overseas investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could take the honourable senator back through this process. COAG has had on its agenda for some time the issue of Commonwealth-state relations in respect of environment law. It is now due for consideration by COAG in July of next year. There is a process taking place at the moment of senior officials negotiating towards that COAG meeting of next year. Part of the negotiation includes the definition of national environmental significance. That is an important debate. It is being developed at both Commonwealth and state level.

ANSWER.PARA: The contribution that we are making to those negotiations has been authorised at cabinet level, and we will be participating in the development of that definition. Issues such as our responsibility under international conventions are obviously those that would fall within national environmental significance, but there are grey areas and that needs to be further explored.

Parallel to that, I will be taking a discussion paper to environment ministers, who are meeting in Brisbane this coming weekend. We will be discussing this with them and giving them the opportunity over the next few months to contribute to that debate as well. As you may be aware, sometimes portfolio ministers feel a little left out by the COAG process. We are seeking to ensure that there is input from state environment ministers as well as an input from states through the whole of government process under COAG.

In addition, in the ensuing months relevant stakeholders, which will include conservation groups and industry, will be given the opportunity to give advice and generate debate. So I expect in the first few months of next year that these lists will be finalised in a form that will be put to COAG, hopefully for endorsement in July. Thereafter, the test as to whether there will be a Commonwealth environmental impact assessment will be on whether it is an issue of national environmental importance rather than on irrelevant issues such as whether there is a foreign investment proposal or whether there is an export permit requirement for some product that might be exported as a result of the development proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be on economics.

—The test will become more relevant to the environmental cause. The issues of powers that flow therefrom are still to be developed, Senator Kernot. They will also be developed as part of this debate and process that will ensue over the next few months.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, you have not necessarily answered how economic significance will be judged, whether or not the corporations power is going to be used in this process and how you actually ensure that states meet national and internationally agreed standards when they fall between those gaps. How can you justify handing total responsibility to a state government which has broken all but five election promises out of 216 on the environment, as reported in today's West Australian , in addition to excising a large area of D'Entrecasteaux National Park for mineral sands mining? Under your proposed changes, would mining in a national park such as D'Entrecasteaux constitute national environmental significance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that you are being somewhat unfair on the Court government in Western Australia. I can think of many examples for which they deserve great credit for their environmental record. I was very pleased to take the woylie off the endangered species list. It was the first time that an Australian animal had been taken off that list. It was largely as a result of initiatives of the Western Australian government that enabled the recovery of that species. I can talk to you about what is occurring in Shark Bay and other areas of Western Australia for which, as I said, the Court government deserves great credit.

ANSWER.PARA: The issue of what may be a lesser environment matter but, nevertheless, has national economic importance, is one of those grey areas that needs to be further explored. But I would argue that it may well be an issue that should be addressed by the federal government as one of the categories that should be looked at, even though you might see it as having a lesser environmental relevance. That is one of these issues that will be debated over the next few months. I would like to think you might contribute constructively to that debate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Newman. Minister, does the federal government stand by the principle that medical treatment arising out of injuries or illnesses sustained in war should not entail an additional financial cost to veterans? Minister, is it a fact that in supporting this principle a $2.70 per week increase in veterans' pensions was introduced to offset the $2.70 cost of pharmaceutical prescriptions and that prescriptions in excess of 52 per year were provided free? How do you reconcile your professed commitment to the principle of free treatment of war injuries with the rise in the cost of pharmaceutical prescriptions from $2.70 to $3.20 without any matching rise in the value of pensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator cannot have been in the chamber when I was asked something similar to this a couple of months ago. Certainly, nearer to the budget this question was raised in the Senate. The answer which I gave then, as I recall, is certainly the answer I will give you now. It does not matter whether I recall it accurately or not, but I will tell you what the truth is because that is what you need. I will be telling you the truth.
—You misled us yesterday. Try to get it right today.
—Senator Faulkner!

—The allowance of $2.70 per week for pharmaceuticals was provided by the previous government. It did recognise the cost of 52 scripts a week at the rate of $2.70 per script. In the budget context, the Department of Veterans' Affairs had produced evidence as to the take‐up rate of pharmaceuticals by veterans. They averaged out, my recollection is, at something like 31 scripts per person.

ANSWER.PARA: We are talking about people here who, one would expect, would be more likely to have more scripts than the average pensioner because we are talking about war induced injuries and illnesses. So the chances are that they would in fact need more rather than less than their contemporaries. That means that at a rate of $2.70 per week, even though the script rate has gone up to $3.20, they are still more than covered for the average usage. Of course, there is still the safety net for those who go above that demand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, is it not the case that this rise means that only 33 prescriptions per year will be provided free and that veterans will have to pay the full prescription fee for those prescriptions in excess of this number up to 52? Can the minister confirm that this means a cost to veterans who require in excess of 52 prescriptions of more than $60?

—I think I partly answered the question. Perhaps you did not listen to the answer. What you need to have emphasised, Senator, is the fact that over the top level of scripts they will be free. The average number of scripts which the pensioners are using is 31. They are getting more recompense than they are in fact using. So most of them, on average, are still receiving more by way of recompense than they actually use, and they get to the safety net as it is unchanged.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy and it relates to greenhouse gas emissions, in particular the proposal by some countries to reduce gas emission levels to 1990 levels by the year 2000.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot, I will ask the question on my own, thank you. Can the minister confirm that he has received a report from ABARE which shows that the real cost to every Australian family will be in the vicinity of $7,600? Can the minister also confirm that the cost to Australia is the highest of any nation, in fact three to five times higher than the cost to the United States or nations in the European Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator O'Chee for his question. Let me say from the outset that the government is committed to fulfilling its commitments under the climate convention and to participating constructively in the ongoing negotiations under the Berlin mandate. Australia will, however, insist that any outcome of greenhouse negotiations is fair in terms of impact and safeguarding Australia's economic and trade interests.

ANSWER.PARA: If we agreed to the uniform targets currently being proposed in the international negotiations, our economy and every Australian would suffer a significantly greater loss than any other developed country. As it stands, the convention on climate change calls upon annex 1 countries, of which Australia is one, to return their greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has estimated that doing so and maintaining the emissions at the 1990 level would in present value terms have a cumulative effect upon our economy equivalent to a loss of some six per cent of our 1996 gross national expenditure. A cost of this magnitude would be equivalent to a loss in the savings of every Australian of $1,900 in 1996 dollars or a reduction in the savings of a family of four of about $7,600.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who gave you that figure?

—This is what the Democrats are proposing. I might say, Senator Kernot, there are none so deaf as those who will not listen. Because of the nature of our economy, Australia's losses would be very much greater than most other developed countries. The Australian economy is heavily dependent on fossil fuels both for electricity generation and for export revenue. Domestic constraints on carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion would damage the competitiveness of Australian industries that are dependent on fossil fuel based energy, such as non-ferrous metals, uranium and zinc, and iron and steel industries.
—You are a disgrace.

—If Senator Margetts wants to get rid of all of those jobs, she should go right ahead and do it. International restrictions on fossil fuel combustion would limit demand for Australian coal exports, with serious adverse consequences for Australian trade in coal and other fossil fuels.

BREAK.PARA: The European Union, some of whose members have been critical of our approach, would suffer much less than a one per cent loss, compared with Australia's six per cent, under stabilisation at 1990 levels. The loss in the United States—strong supporters of uniform targets—would be just over one per cent.

It is interesting to note that Australia's contribution to greenhouse gas is 1.4 per cent globally. By comparison, I understand the US contribution is in excess of 25 per cent. These differences in the cost to different countries reflect the different structures of their economies and differences in trading patterns and trading partners. Clearly, the more severe uniform target proposals—such as reducing emissions to 20 per cent below 1990 levels by 2010, which some countries have proposed—would involve even greater losses to Australia. Accordingly, the government will continue to actively campaign for all countries to bear their fair share of the effort in addressing climate change.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Essential Services for Remote Aboriginal Communities

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. When was the Australian Defence Force first informed of the government's plan to use the army to assist remote Aboriginal communities? What are the financial arrangements relating to this proposal? In particular, what arrangements have been made to supplement Defence for the additional costs? Given the fact that the army now contracts out to private firms, will the army be buying or leasing necessary equipment to assist remote Aboriginal communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator West really wanted that amount of detail from the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, it is a pity she did not give me advance notice. I would have been very happy to get her that detail.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I will still get you the detail, but now you will have to wait 24 hours.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The persistent interjections are in breach of the standing orders.
—I am happy to add to what I have just said by saying that one of the things that have surprised me in the press coverage of this initiative—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, do you think they want to hear any answer about this issue?
—Order!

—One of the things that Senator West of all people should know is that the Australian Defence Force is extremely good at training people in all sorts of ways and in all sorts of areas. They are specialists. They do very well. One of the things that the press coverage of this initiative has not focused on at all, to my knowledge—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Gosh, they do rabbit on, don't they?

BREAK.PARA: I would have thought one of the greatest needs for Aboriginal communities—certainly from my visits to Aboriginal communities around Australia over the last 10 years—is for the young people in those communities to have training in building and maintenance of their own communities.

One of the things that I hope will come out of this really excellent initiative is that young people in those communities will be trained by the army on the job. So often the contractors have come in, done a job, left and not provided the training. It is very important, I believe, for the long-term good of the individuals and for the continuing good of the communities, that there are people resident in those communities who are able to repair taps.

Some of us remember former Senator Graham Richardson, before a TV camera, pointing to a tap and saying, `Isn't this terrible?' And it was terrible. One of the worst things about it was that there were young people there who had the time and the opportunity, but not the training, to repair the taps.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —While the rabble opposite makes a noise, I stress that this is a serious matter.
—Order!

—Clearly the opposition is not interested in the issue of training young Aboriginal people in isolated communities. The government believes that bringing the army in to undertake some of these tasks—as I understand it, basically like pilot programs—will be an important element. I will be happy to get further details for Senator West. Obviously, there was a great deal of specifics in her question that only the Minister for Defence can provide.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. A question similar to this was asked by Senator Margetts on 19 November. I repeat my question. When was the ADF—not the minister; the Australian Defence Force—first informed of the government's plan to use the army to assist remote Aboriginal communities? What are the financial arrangements relating to this proposal? In particular, what arrangements have been made to supplement Defence for the additional costs? Given the fact that the army now contracts out to private firms, will the army be buying or leasing the necessary equipment to assist remote Aboriginal communities? That is what I would like an answer to, please.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West may not realise that my son was in fact an army engineer. I know very well the capabilities of army engineers.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—He would be cringing with embarrassment.
—Would you like to be quiet for a change?
—Order! Senator Newman, resume your seat. The behaviour this afternoon has been persistently in breach of standing orders, and wilfully so, by a number of senators. I call Senator Newman.

—I was going on to say this. I am proud, as I would hope most Australians are, of the level of training that those people have been given in the army. The engineers are very well equipped and able to undertake some of these roles, and Senator West should know that after her long association with the Defence portfolio when she lost her seat as a senator.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, Senator West was repeating questions which she asked before. They are not supplementary questions. I have said I will get that detail for her from the minister, but I really wonder whether she is interested in the answers at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Has the government sought legal advice on the implications of removing, before 1 July, immunities from state and territory laws currently enjoyed by telecom munications carriers? If so, from whom? Minister, will you table this advice?

—This is a hypothetical question, because we are not proposing to remove powers and immunities before 1 July. Therefore, there is no basis on which we would seek legal advice in respect of that matter.
—I thank the Minister for his response, but why has the government indicated that it is likely to be sued by Optus, I think it was reported, without such legal advice?

—You are asking me if I could tell you why Optus is suggesting that it might sue the government? I am not suggesting anything. Optus is entitled to take whatever advice it likes. If it has legal rights and a cause for action then, presumably, it will pursue them. The fact is that we have indicated an intention to tighten the existing code in a number of respects. That does not constitute removing all the powers and immunities. I have said to you and others—I hope the others, at least, have understood this—that we are not in the business of welshing on the arrangements that were put in place by Mr Beazley in 1991, when he was minister for communications.
—You are saying it. You voted for that legislation.

—The fact is that we are supportive of arrangements that are designed to enable Australia to have a world‐class communications system. It is very disappointing that your obsession seems to be with finding ways in which you can basically knock that on the head. We think competition is important, and I hope that you do, too. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Health Care System in New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Do you realise that your government's planned $34 million worth of cuts to the New South Wales health care system will mean the closure of 400 hospital beds and the loss of 900 doctor and nursing positions and that this will have a devastating effect on the people of New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a response here from the minister for health, because Senator Neal's questions are so very predictable. Perhaps she is not aware of the fact that cost shifting by the states and territories has been a longstanding problem for Australia's health system which was not addressed by the previous government; that is, the shifting of the practice of managing patient care so that costs that should be borne in the hospital system, which are the states' responsibility, are shifted to the Commonwealth through the Medicare system.

ANSWER.PARA: Cost shifting activities are estimated to be of the order of $300 million a year—effectively taking from the Commonwealth, through the Medicare benefits and pharmaceutical benefits schemes, $300 million every year on top of the nearly $5 billion the Commonwealth pays the states towards providing public hospital services.

In the past, Labor governments have attempted to implicate individual doctors and hold them responsible for participation in cost shifting schemes by states and territories. Dr Wooldridge has taken a more constructive approach and has asked for doctors' help to get better information and data collections to support dealings with the states and territories in relation to cost shifting activities. Suggestions by the AMA that doctors who do not provide information on cost shifting to the government will be fined are clearly false. That is not the intention of the government.

The government is tackling the problem of cost shifting where the problem really lies; that is, with the states and territories. We are holding health ministers to the promises they made at the June 1995 meeting in Alice Springs by annually recovering growth in cost shifting since that time. This amounts to around $75 million a year.

In the 1996-97 budget, the government announced that adjustments totalling $75 million would be made, and a provisional distribution based on per capita shares was included in the budget estimates. Dr Wooldridge recently approved the distribution of the $75 million in 1996-97, based on a combination of states' relative cost shifting in 1995-96 and states' per capita expenditure under the diagnostic imaging and radiology parts of the Medicare benefits schedule in 1995-96, relative to a national average under the diagnostic imaging and radiology parts of the MBS. Where there is more scope for cost shifting, per capita expenditure in New South Wales was 24 per cent higher than the average of all other states. The cost shifting adjustments represent only two per cent of the $1.5 billion of hospital funding grants which will be paid to New South Wales in 1996-97.

Even after this adjustment, HFG payments to New South Wales in 1996-97 are still one per cent higher than they were in 1995-96. It should also be noted that, even after adjustment is made for the cost shifting penalties, the funding which New South Wales receives on a per capita basis, resulting from the Medicare hospital funding agreement, is higher than the average funding which other states receive.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. The minister stated in her higher education statement that $72 million would be applied to indigenous higher education. This is significantly more than the previous government's commitment. Specifically, the government committed itself to spending $6.5 million on a number of indigenous higher education centres in areas such as public health, law, education, employment, language, environmental management, and housing and community design. Could the minister please inform the Senate of the progress of this initiative, particularly the benefits of these centres to indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ellison for that question. He has had a longstanding interest in the welfare of indigenous Australians, and recognises—as I think all senators do—that the degree of disadvantage faced by indigenous Australians is unacceptable. It is unacceptable to me, to the government and, I would hope, to all senators.

ANSWER.PARA: The gap between indigenous and non‐indigenous education participation and attainment is still significant. The year 12 retention rate, for example, for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students is only 31 per cent compared with 73 per cent for non‐indigenous Australians. We do know that indigenous Australians who have had the benefit of tertiary qualifications enjoy similar employment prospects to other Australians.

Therefore, in this year's budget, as Senator Ellison says, the government did announce $72 million over the next three years to improve access by indigenous Australians to higher education, and that represents a significant increase over the former government's proposals. This additional funding will support improved outcomes in the university sector and includes funding for new indigenous higher education centres at several universities.

BREAK.PARA: It was with great pleasure that I announced on the weekend funding of $8.8 million over three years for the establishment of five indigenous higher education centres to pursue important matters for indigenous Australians. I am pleased, and I hope all senators are, that this is an increase of $2.3 million on the amount that was actually announced in the budget.

The centres will be for high level teaching and research in vital areas such as indigenous health, curriculum and research development, and natural and cultural resource management. The centres will improve indigenous Australians' access to higher education and boost their educational outcomes. They will be located at the Curtin University of Technology, the University of Newcastle, the Northern Territory University, the University of South Australia and the University of Western Australia, and will be funded with between $1.7 million and $2 million over the next three years.

The submissions were assessed by an expert panel which was headed by an independent chair, Dr Bill Jonas, Director of the National Museum. These centres will provide a focus for indigenous research and will directly contribute expertise and knowledge in their respective disciplines to benefit indigenous communities. They will encourage the incorporation of indigenous Australian perspectives into courses and teaching and help the general community understand indigenous knowledge and learning.

Indigenous people will play an important part in managing these centres. Up to three indigenous teaching and research fellowships will be awarded to each of the centres to encourage the development of indigenous scholarships in key areas of research. The competitive selection process has already led to increased cooperation between universities, and has stimulated some creative thinking about the development of indigenous higher education. The successful proposals include formal sharing arrangements with other institutions so the whole indigenous community will benefit.

Madam President, in conclusion, Senator Ellison is right in highlighting this issue. The government did commit to spending more money, and I am pleased to identify to the Senate that we have spent $2.3 million more than we actually thought we would be able to in the budget.

Senator the Hon Bob Collins—Question Without Notice—7 November 1996
Electoral Data
Hansard Reference: Page 5072
On 7 November, Senator the Hon Bob Collins asked the Minister representing the Attorney‐General:

Can the Minister confirm that an Australian Federal Police investigation has proven that the claim by the Member for the Northern Territory, Mr Dondas, that he obtained confidential material from the electoral data in the Northern Territory prior to the recent federal election from `a source in the Australian Electoral Commission' was proven to be utterly false?

Can the Minister confirm that the investigation found that a person or persons unknown in the Department of the Chief Minister in the Northern Territory provided the material to a Brisbane based firm, Feedback Services, which provided data related services to the Liberal Party of Australia, who then passed this material back to the Country Liberal Party in the territory for use by Mr Dondas?

Because the Australian Federal Police have no jurisdiction to pursue what happened to the material once it was provided to the Northern Territory authorities, will the federal government release the AFP report and support calls for an independent inquiry into the misuse of Australian Electoral Commission data in the Northern Territory by the Northern Territory authorities?
The Attorney‐General has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

I am advised that, in March 1996, the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) referred an allegation of unauthorised access to electoral information to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for investiga tion. The AFP completed its investigation in September and provided its findings to the AEC. The AFP concluded that no Commonwealth charges would be preferred and the AEC was advised accordingly.
I am further advised that the Northern Territory Police are undertaking inquiries into related matters and it is therefore inappropriate for me to comment further.

Consistent with the approach taken by successive Ministers responsible for the Australian Federal Police, I will not release an AFP investigation report. The public release of police investigation reports is not in the public interest in cases where charges have not been laid and allegations not tested in a court.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Faulkner asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, about women doctors. I now have additional information, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE
SENATOR FAULKNER—25 NOVEMBER 1996
WOMEN DOCTORS
Senator Faulkner asked Senator Newman:

Are you aware of claims by the Australian Medical Association that the federal health ministers' proposal to restrict new doctors' access to Medical provider numbers will lead to a reduction in the number of women doctors? Has your attention been drawn to claims by the AMA Women in Medicine Committee that Dr Wooldridge's proposal, which will further increase the inflexibility of postgraduate training schemes and limit practice options, will discriminate against women doctors and medical students? Minister, are you aware that medical graduates who are unable to access an accredited training position will no longer be able to secure a provider number and practise medicine part‐time?

I wish to ask a supplementary question. Would you concede that these arrangements will reduce the level of choice for women wishing to arrange their lives, flexibly secure in the knowledge that one day they can return to full‐time or part‐time practice?
Senator Newman has provided the following answer:
The Government does not have any evidence to suggest that women will be disadvantaged by the measure.

If it were true that women were disadvantaged by the requirement to undertake training before entering general practice then we would expect to see female non‐specialists over represented in the other medical practitioner (OMPs). In fact, both the OMP and GP categories of non specialist have very similar proportions of women. In 1994/95:
30.9% of non specialists were female;
30.64% of general practitioners
31.55% of OMPs
Source: Medicare data

The proportion of women entering medical schools has increased dramatically in recent years. As a consequence, the representation of women in the medical workforce has been improving significantly. In 1993‐94 29% of all GPs were women. That figure for 1995‐96 is 32%. However, in the under 35 year age group, women represent 54% of all GPs.

Supporting the position of properly trained GPs will therefore support women who have chosen general practice as their vocation and make it attractive for women to continue choosing general practice by reducing the competition from less well qualified doctors.

For women doctors who choose not to become GPs, there will be a range of alternative options as there are now. These include public hospital positions, other post graduate training in specialty fields, salaried positions in hospitals, community health centres, government, the non‐Government sector, private enterprise and academia. The majority of these employers offer part‐time work.

The Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee (AMWAC) is also pursuing the issue of increased flexibility and part time work in relation to hospital career positions so that this type of work is better suited to the needs of women doctors. One recommendation the Working Party is that the Committee of the Presidents of Medical Colleges should undertake a major review of College arrangements to facilitate female specialist training and practice.

The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) Training Program, for example, has options to accommodate both part time and suspended training. A part time trainee in the RACGP Training Program could easily take a longer period eg 8 years to complete the program.

Issues around fairness and gender equity in post graduate training are of concern but are not directly related to this measure. The Minister has indicated that he will vigorously pursue these issues with the medical colleges should it be demonstrated that a problem really does exist.

I am aware that medical graduates who are unable to access an accredited training position will no longer be able to secure a provider number and practise medicine part‐time, or full time, without appropriate training. The importance of post graduate training has been stated again and again by the Australian Medical Association, the professional Colleges, Jenny Macklin's National Health Strategy, the Rural Doctors Association, the Deans of the Medical Schools, even the Australian Medical Students Association. Medical schools produce undifferentiated graduates, that is young doctors with basic training, but not the expertise needed to practice without further specialised training or supervision in a field. This policy will ensure that all newly registered doctors complete specific training in their field before entering private practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some interest and some amazement to two speeches from the Democrats and the Greens talking about environmental responsibility. If they have any real interest in environmental responsibility, they have the classic opportunity to do something tangible about it, that is, to help the government pour $1 billion into the environment—the greatest investment in the environment that ever has taken place in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: These people, who have spoken for five minutes about environmental responsibility, have the classic opportunity to do it. And what are they going to do? They are going to look after the interests of a multinational company which they seem to think, from what I understand them to be saying, is of more interest than the environment—a multinational company that in the past has not been terribly efficient, has not been terribly good to Australian consumers and has not been terribly efficient in the cost of producing and getting on with proper telecommunications. Where is the environmental responsibility? Of course, they do not want to hear about that. All we hear from the Greens and the Democrats is whinge, whinge, whinge.

Yesterday I had the opportunity and the pleasure of being with the Antarctic Division of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories in Hobart. I was very pleased to be able to see just a fraction of the very good work those people are doing. I was pleased to learn of the tremendous work that the Antarctic Division is doing in measuring the ozone layer—and the difficulties that the world is experiencing in that regard—and in looking at the questions of greenhouse gas. In fact, the Australian Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, through the Antarctic Division, is making a major worldwide contribution to our understanding of the depletion of the ozone layer and the impacts of greenhouse gas. I would have thought that the Democrats and the Greens should have been congratulating Australia at every opportunity instead of knocking us all the time on the great, world‐leading work we are doing in this field.

I know that the Greens and the Democrats are the high tax parties. They have always wanted to tax ordinary Australians. Does Senator Kernot still want to charge $1 a litre for petrol and put up the taxes of ordinary Australians on the petrol they use? The carbon tax issue keeps coming up. I am not sure that I listened intently enough to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy, when he was answering, but I understood him to say that the Democrats' proposal would add $7,000 to the costs of every Australian family. This is what we have come to expect from the Democrats—just adding to the taxes paid by ordinary Australians.

Senator Hill has emphasised, and I want to repeat it, that Australia's contribution to greenhouse gases is 1.4 per cent of the global total. So we are a pretty small player. Any percentage is too much, and of course this government will continue to work towards reductions of that. But, as Senator Hill said, the Democrats and the Greens are proposing that we export out of Australia the environmentally sensitive minerals processing we have now and put it into developing countries which do not have the standards we have, which will quickly pick up any shortfall of Australian export material in the minerals field and which will do it in a much less environmentally sensible and sustainable way.

Not only would the Greens and the Democrats have us pushing these mineral processings into less environmentally sensitive areas but they also want to export Australian jobs. Mr Deputy President, as you and honourable senators would know, this government is determined to make sure that there is proper employment for everyone, that we do that in the most environmentally sensitive way and that we continue the good work that the Antarctic Division—in fact, all parts of the Australian science community—is doing towards something tangible about the greenhouse impact on the ozone layer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —For those who are following this debate, that was the contribution from the new Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Senator Ian Macdonald). The best he can do is get to his feet and lambaste those people who are speaking for the environment—to get stuck into the community that is concerned about the environment—and try to do them in.

ANSWER.PARA: He was unable to speak for the environment any more than the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), who preceded him, who got up in this place in response to Senator Kernot to predict doom and gloom because she spoke as an environmentalist. Because she is expressing concern about the direction he is going, he comes up with the old line that she wants to close down agriculture and that she wants to stop exports—except for downstream processing, which she wants to send offshore. It is time they woke up to the fact that Australians are much more literate on the environment than that.

Senator Hill has today by selective announcement and by answers to questions in this place said that he is about to embark on a monumental shift in the balance of power as far as the protection of the environment in Australia is concerned. Every Australian concerned about the environment must have alarm bells ringing. Every Australian concerned about the pretty odious record of this government on the environment must be concerned about what is afoot. Senator Hill has said that he is about to talk with the state governments on how they would like to see the powers of protection for the environment divvyed up among the states.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?
—The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer said, `What is wrong with that?' Senator Hill said, `What is wrong with the Court government's record?'
—Excellent.

—`Excellent,' says the parliamentary secretary. This is the Court government that has been involved in carving up national parks, in logging some of the world's grandest eucalypt forests and a whole range of environmentally desperate acts which have led the West Australian to record today that they have been unable to keep their election promises, except for a handful.
—That is a lie.
—Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that interjection because it was unparliamentary.
—Is it unparliamentary to say, `That is a lie?'
—Yes.
—I withdraw it then.
—I think that is fair enough.
—That is a gross misstatement of the truth.
—Everybody can read the newspaper. If I remember correctly, Senator Margetts said that less than 10 of its more than 200 promises have been kept.
—Read the paper; so the paper is wrong too.

—The paper may be wrong. Everybody in the world is wrong except members of the government. All Australians are wrong except members of the government. What I am talking about is Senator Hill. Following his environmental record of turning his back on Hinchinbrook, uranium exports, his greenhouse responsibilities, his responsibilities to curb logging in our forests and a whole range of other issues, Senator Hill is now saying, `I am going to divest important environmental responsibilities to state governments.'
—Tell the truth; are you capable of telling the truth, that is the big question here. You are not capable. Why don't you tell the truth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —You might try to shout me down, but you will have your turn. I will not be shouted down by you. The fact is that, had the philosophy of this government and its assessment of what are state and what are national responsibilities held sway previously, the Franklin River would now be flooded.

ANSWER.PARA: I came to Canberra in June 1992 when the state government, the Robin Gray government—the brown leech ridden ditch, Mr Grey described the Franklin as being—was about to send in the bulldozers. We made an appeal to coalition Prime Minister Fraser to protect the Franklin using Commonwealth powers. We had a petition containing over 30,000 signatures appealing to that end.

What did he say? He said, `Don't come up to me when you lose at state level and try to get the Commonwealth government to intervene on what is a state matter.' The Franklin River was a state matter according to the coalition. The federal government was not going to take responsibility for it. As we know, the Fraser government lost office over a number of issues, not least the Franklin River. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Sherry today, relating to the superannuation entitlements of Commonwealth employees.

The essential aspect of the answer by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, was that there is no intention of reducing public sector remuneration, which includes superannuation. The question related to a statement in a letter written to Commonwealth public servants by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when Leader of the Opposition. The letter stated:
I give you my rock‐solid guarantee that the Coalition will not cut and destroy public sector superannuation schemes or the entitlements of existing and prospective Commonwealth Government employees.

Our policy on public sector superannuation is clear and unequivocal and was set out in our superannuation and public administration policies released last week. The relevant section of the superannuation policy is attached. It does not canvass or propose the reduction of employer contributions to public sector superannuation.

Senator Sherry asked whether the minister could assure the Senate that the government was still committed to that statement—yes or no. He got what I would term a rather glib and equivocal answer to that question.

You can fool all of the people some of the time and some of the people all of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all of the time. In relation to this matter, you have to compare the answer to Prime Minister Howard's assurance to public sector workers—the clear and unequivocal guarantee. I would categorise the response as political speak. I give credit to Senator Abetz for that term because he used it to describe a broken promise made to Tasmanian public sector workers by the then Premier of Tasmania Ray Groom.
There is an article in today's Financial Review by Louise Dodson headed `Bureaucracy to get a corporate look with CEOs at the top'. The journalist wrote:
In a bid to open up the bureaucracy, public servants will be encouraged to move more freely between the Federal and State public services and private‐sector corporations.
Yet while this is definitely a worthy sentiment, public‐service superannuation schemes are a major impediment for moves that are more than just token exchanges.

And although the paper indicates public‐service salaries and conditions should be deregulated to encourage greater movement, it still remains unlikely that pay levels would match those in the private sector.

I think there is a conflict between what the Prime Minister said and the implications of what Mr Reith is saying in relation to the reform of public sector salaries. Public Service pay and conditions, according to Louise Dodson, are to be deregulated. The package of conditions, Senator Kemp says, includes superannuation. So do we take from that that Senator Kemp is not giving the assurance—he is saying that it is going to be deregulated? Why could he not simply endorse the comments made by Mr Howard? Why could he not say that there was a rock solid guarantee? Perhaps it is because the guarantee is as rock solid as the other guarantees that Mr Howard gave before the election, which have since been dishonoured.

BREAK.PARA: In the statement that Senator Kemp made there is no guarantee for future employees. There is no specific superannuation promise. It is all a package. Is he saying that employees, present and future, will be encouraged to bargain away superannuation for a fair wage? (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE SAME SITTINGS
CHILD CARE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

Amendments to the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Child Care Act 1972 are proposed to implement changes announced in the 1996 Budget. These changes will reduce the rate of benefit for the Childcare Cash Rebate from 30% to 20% for families with a combined income greater than the cut offs for the Family Tax Initiative, from 1 April 1997, and remove operational subsidies from child care centres, except in exceptional circumstances, from 1 July 1997. Guidelines will be developed to define exceptional circumstances.

It is necessary to seek passage in the Spring sittings to ensure the implementation date of 1 April 1997 can be achieved. Moreover, significant development work is needed to implement and publicise these initiatives well in advance of the implementation date.
If the Bill is not dealt with in one sitting it is possible that any delays in the Senate may prevent implementation on 1 April 1997 or jeopardise the smooth transition to the new arrangements.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Health and Family Services
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1996 SPRING SITTINGS
STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (WAITING PERIOD) BILL 1996

The proposed Bill will amend the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 by introducing a two year (104 week) waiting period for newly arrived migrant access to AUSTUDY benefits. The waiting period will, as a general rule, apply to Australian permanent residents and New Zealand citizens who arrive in Australia on or after 1 January 1997. The measure was announced in the 1996‐97 Budget.

The Bill must be introduced and passed in the 1996 Spring Sittings to meet the Government's intention for implementation by 1 January 1997. This will ensure that people who may be affected by the measure will know the scope of the legislation before the commencement of the 1997 academic year.

If the Bill is not introduced and passed in the 1996 Spring Sittings the date of commencement may need to be altered to ensure that the waiting period is not applied retrospectively. A delayed date of commencement would erode forecast Budget savings from the measure. Alternatively, if the commencement date remained unchanged, migrants who arrived in Australia after 1 January 1997 and received AUSTUDY would be liable to repay their benefits after passage of the Bill.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1996 SPRING SITTINGS
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 3) 1996
Purpose of the proposed Bill: To give effect to nine taxation measures including seven measures announced in the 1996‐97 Budget.
The Budget measures are:

PARA.TAB: to close off new syndicates qualifying for the research and development (R&D) tax concession and to "fine‐tune" some other aspects of the R&D tax concession including a change to the level of concession given to certain R&D expenditures
to extend capital gains tax treatment to gains and losses by lending institutions on realisation of eligible equity investments in small to medium enterprises (SMEs)
to halt the development of certain tax aggressive schemes (known as "multi‐dipping" arrangements) which are contrary to the intention of the infrastructure borrowings tax concession
to deny co‐operatives a deduction for the repayment of loans from a government of the Commonwealth or a State
to remove the exemption for income from the sale, transfer or assignment of rights to mine for gold or for any prescribed metal or prescribed mineral
to provide an income tax rebate to certain non‐pensioners of pension age
to increase the threshold above which medical expenses will qualify for the medical expenses rebate.

SPEECH.PARA: The two non‐Budget measures are:

PARA.TAB: to rectify an anomaly in the income tax law which allows non‐rebatable annuities to be converted to rebatable eligible termination payment (ETP) annuities or rebatable superannuation pensions

to give effect to an announcement by the former Government on 3 July 1995 to introduce measures that provide for taxation treatment of the various Government entities which have been, or are being, privatised and entering the Commonwealth tax net. The measure provides for the taxation treatment generally for all exempt entities which become taxable.

SPEECH.PARA: Reasons for urgency: All of the measures commence during the 1996‐97 year or earlier. Introduction and passage in the 1996 Spring sittings of Parliament is crucial to allay uncertainty in the community over the measures and to protect the revenue.

Result if Bill is not dealt with in these sittings: It will not be possible to ensure that the measures can be properly implemented and enforced in a timely manner and it will be difficult for taxpayers to comply with the proposed changes to the law. This will result in additional compliance and administrative costs.
Circulated with the authority of the Assistant Treasurer
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE DURING THE 1996 SPRING SITTINGS
CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1996
IMPORT PROCESSING CHARGES BILL 1996
CUSTOMS DEPOT LICENSING CHARGES BILL 1996
The Import Processing and Customs Depot Licensing Charges Bills propose the introduction of charges relating to import transaction processing by the Australian Customs Service.
The Customs Amendment Bill proposes amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to:

PARA.TAB: reduce from $1000 to $250 the maximum value of goods consigned through the Post which are exempt from import entry requirements;
introduce a licensing regime for depot operators with annual licence fees; and
reduce the fee for duty refund applications and limit the number of circumstances where the fee is not payable.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for both the Amendment Bill and the Charges Bills has arisen from the Government's Budget decision that Customs introduce charges to recover the costs of all commercial Customs activities directly and indirectly required to process the importation of goods. The new charges are proposed to apply from 1 January 1997 to deliver expected savings of $23m in the 1996‐97 financial year and $46m ongoing thereafter. The 1 January commencement date will allow time for Customs to complete computer system enhancements to facilitate collection methods and will coincide with half yearly cashflow and reporting requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In the few minutes that I have to comment on the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation, I firstly point out that the matter referred to the committee deals with the issue of the Liberal government's proposed deeming on the superannuation assets of persons who turn 55 and the offsetting of the deemed income on their superannuation against unemployment benefits, disability or sickness benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure will hit hard at some 67,000 Australians in the short term. It will hit a great many more Australians in the longer term, but I will come to that shortly. This measure is to take effect from 20 September next year. It will hurt unemployed, sick and disabled Australians quite dramatically.

People who will be hurt by this measure include a rail worker from Port Pirie in South Australia. He has just turned 55 and has a relatively small amount of superannuation of just over $100,000. He has been made redundant and has no chance of finding another job. He believed that he would be able to put aside his superannuation to the age of 60 and, at least to some extent, live on the earnings of that superannuation. He now finds he has to unravel his retirement plans because his superannuation is deemed to earn income at the age of 55.

I have mentioned that this will hit hard at the retirement plans of some 67,000 Australians. The committee believes that potentially it will hurt hundreds of thousands of Australians over the next 10 to 15 years. There are two reasons for this. Firstly, the superannuation guarantee which came in some four years ago and the general advent and spreading of superannuation to all Australian workers mean that those Australians reaching the age of 55 in the next 10 to 15 years will have significantly more superannuation. This is illustrated by the fact that in 1983 the average balance in superannuation was only $13,000. Today it is $40,000. Within 10 years we are likely to see the average balance in superannuation accounts for nine out of 10 Australians reach $100,000. This measures affects any person with more than $45,000 in superannuation.

Another reason for the increasing number—probably 360,000—of Australians eventually being affected by this measure is the ageing population. There are approximately 1.2 million Australians aged between 45 and 50 and almost one million Australians between the age of 50 and 55. When they reach the age of 55, they will be deemed to be earning on their superannuation. If they are unemployed—and apparently one in five Australians at the age of 55 is unemployed—they will have to draw down part or all of their superannuation in order to offset the loss, in part or whole, of their unemployment or disability pension.

This is truly a measure that hits very hard at elderly Australians, particularly Australians who have turned 55, and particularly Australians who went to considerable trouble during their lives to put aside some money for superannuation for their retirement income. When they are unemployed, when they hit 55, they are hit for six if they are unemployed, sick or disabled. This is truly a disastrous measure for ageing Australians at a time of great uncertainty in their life, when they are attempting to find other employment.

BREAK.PARA: The government's excuse for this measure is that it is there to catch millionaires. The evidence from the department before the committee is that only 93 per cent of the people who will be caught by this measure have less than $200,000 in superannuation. Nine out of 10 people have less than $200,000 in superannuation. They are not millionaires. They are electricians, bank clerks, former rail workers and shopkeepers. We even had the tragic case of a woman whose husband is on a disability pension because he has cancer of the brain. They have to draw on their superannuation over the next two years otherwise they have no income. This is truly a dreadful measure.

To conclude, there are a number of other undesirable aspects of this legislation. Many of the 67,000 people who have put aside money for superannuation have entered into long-term retirement commitments. They have purchased annuities or pensions. They now have to unravel their arrangements in many cases. They will be subject to additional fees and charges. There is a contradictory test. If you want to access your superannuation benefits, you have to apply to the trustee and state that you are, in effect, unemployed in order to access the money.

There is also a significant impact on the budget. The government will save money in the short term but it will cost it money in the long term when those people have drawn down on their superannuation and when they turn 65, they will receive a higher part or full pension. We asked the government for costing or modelling on this issue. None could be provided. Also, the measure will have a significant impact on national saving. Again, we asked the government for modelling on the impact on national saving. None has been carried out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to this report of the Select Committee on Superannuation.
—Is leave granted?

—Yes, leave will be granted but I point out that there was a statement made earlier by the Manager of Government Business on this issue. My understanding was that general agreement had been reached in relation to this matter. We are not pressing the point at the moment. My understanding is that the manager went around and sought agreement. Hopefully, this might be the last time.

—The Australian Democrats are happy to endorse the majority report of the Select Committee on Superannuation on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996. We agree with the report that the government proposal to add superannuation into the assets test for social security benefits for beneficiaries aged over 55 was poorly thought out and would reduce retirement savings. This measure, announced in the August budget, was estimated to save $92 million in 1997-98, falling to $67 million in the following year by cutting benefits to over 67,000 people.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee majority report found that the policy cuts right across retirement incomes policy, with very little thought to the short-term or long-term consequences. It is a bad piece of policy to count superannuation within the assets test used to reduce social security when often the person could not access their superannuation even if they wanted to. Furthermore, it is false to say that the government will save up to $92 million a year when the savings are earned by reducing the person's retirement savings, thereby increasing their reliance on the age pension in retirement.

The Democrats will be prepared to support the inclusion of large superannuation accounts—for instance, those over $250,000 in the assets test—but only in relation to funds accumulated prospectively. The measures should not be retrospective in our view. We would insist that the government also ensure that superannuation regulations allow access to the funds if they are needed without taxation, ISC or fund exit fee penalties. This would prevent those with very large superannuation funds from abusing the social security system while those with limited resources could keep their superannuation for their retirement. But it was not acceptable that these people, having saved for their retirement, should have the rules changed in midstream and have to raid their retirement savings to fund periods of disability or unemployment.

The Democrats also endorse the call by the majority for more detailed research into the rorting to prevent people double-dipping on DSS pensions when they were effectively retired. I commend this report to the Senate.
