TALK.START.PARA: —Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) gives effect to the June Premiers Conference outcomes to no longer exempt from sales tax motor vehicles purchased by state governments and local governments. It has been estimated that the sales tax on cars would cost state governments around $300 million a year and local governments approximately $50 million a year. The reasons for the change were to raise revenue and to put state government and local government bodies in the same position with regard to the sales tax and prevent deterioration in the revenue base due to the increasing use of cars as part of government salary packages.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition will not be opposing this bill, which is a compromise. It is a compromise to try to dig the government out of the appalling mess that it created for itself when shortly after the election, to the combined anger—I might add, significant anger—of state and local governments around Australia, it ratted fairly spectacularly on a number of pre-election commitments that had been given in the run-up to the 2 March election.

PARA.BREAK: During that period, we had not caught up with this new piece of political speak of core and non-core promises. We did not hear about all that until after the election. This certainly was an unequivocal breach of clear commitments that had been given prior to the elec tion. You do not have to rely on me for authority on that; you simply have to look at the chorus of protest from the political colleagues of this government around Australia after it happened. Dean Brown, the Premier of South Australia, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that's simply an underhand means of trying to grab funding from the States and I stress the Federal Government has taken soft options they, for the last 10‐12 years, have cut monies to the States but expanded their own income and expenditure very considerably,
. . .. the Federal Government have broken a number of significant election promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tch, tch.

—I am glad, Minister, from your reaction—your interjection of `Tch, tch'—that you think it is such a big joke. I am sure the Premier of South Australia will be interested to hear that this newly appointed minister in the Senate thinks it is a matter of no account whatsoever that those commitments given by his colleagues prior to the election were torn apart immediately afterwards. Premier Brown did in fact accurately state that you have broken a number of significant election promises with this measure. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . they have not maintained the general grants to the States as we have an agreement to do, and as they promised they would.

That is in fact the case. As we know right across Australia, in all states and territories, there was a significant reduction in the level of federal government support which this coalition in the campaign promised they would maintain. The Premier of South Australia went on to say:
It smacks of a Government in Canberra that is very arrogant indeed and has dealt a very severe blow to Commonwealth/State relations.

I could go on to quote the leaders of a number of other governments around Australia and, indeed, the reaction by local government across Australia who saw very mistakenly that they perhaps had some allies in this new coalition government because of all the commitments, hand over heart, that were made prior to 2 March about the new birth of recognition of local government. They, along with the state governments, soon found out how misplaced was their trust on that score.
The quotations would occupy the entire time I have available for this debate, so I will simply conclude with what the Victorian Treasurer had to say about his colleagues on the same issue. He said:
I think it's a very black day for the new Federal Government.
He is talking about the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) here, Honest John. He said:
The central appeal to the people of Australia was that he—
that is, the Prime Minister—

could be trusted, that he would keep his promise and he would honour his commitments and here he's broken no less than five commitments. Two election promises. No tax increases. This is a tax increase. He will maintain State funding. As you've rightly pointed out this morning, it in fact takes another $600 million off the States in addition to the amount he's claiming as the offset.
He went on to say in respect of the Treasurer (Mr Costello):

. . . the $619 million of grants. They are the second instalment of a three year agreement which was finalised at last year's Premiers' Conference. So Mr Costello is essentially repudiating the agreement made only 12 months ago.

I know that all honourable senators will recall these statements. It is not all that common in this country to be this violently attacked by your own political colleagues, particularly for a newly elected government. The Victorian conservatives are very close in political terms to this government, but the Victorian Treasurer went on to say again in respect of the government's commitments:
. . . that is a flagrant repudiation of, not only his election commitments—
he is talking about the Prime Minister—
but the agreement.
He continued:

These burdens flow through to State taxpayers and they'll have to fund these burdens, and Mr Costello is taxing them by stealth in flagrant breach of his election commitment, upon which he was elected with an overwhelming mandate by the people.

I think the final quotation which represents just how far this government's conservative colleagues in Victoria went was the last part of this interview with the Victorian Treasurer—and, remember, he is a tory Treasurer—when he said:
. . . a very bad start by the new Howard Government, that they're repudiating fundamental election commitments, they're doing more damage to State taxpayers than even Keating did.
That, of course, is from an ultra‐conservative Victorian Treasurer.

That is the background to this piece of legislation that we are seeing off in the Senate this afternoon. It is, as I have said, a compromise bill to help the Treasurer save face after having been done over comprehensively by his own Liberal colleagues at the Premiers Conference.

In a press statement on 19 February 1996, the current Treasurer promised the states and territories a fixed share of Commonwealth revenue. This was going to be revenue neutral. He also, I might say, guaranteed the then current level of services to the states. These are the broken commitments that the Premier of South Australia and the Treasurer of Victoria were referring to in the quotes I have just delivered.

Instead of that, the government broke a major promise not to increase taxes. If it had not been for the Liberal premiers, who publicly monstered these changes, the increased tax burdens on the states, territories and local government would have been even greater.

Far from being revenue neutral, this bill ensures that it will be revenue negative for the states. What has happened to the promise of a fixed share of Commonwealth revenue? What has happened to it is that it has sunk without trace, like so many other Howard government promises. As it is, the government has forced over $1½ billion in cuts onto the states, on top of the callous and absolutely indiscriminate cuts contained in the budget.

Cutting this level of funding from the states is just one substantial step in the government's efforts—and they are across-the-board now, and I think they are actually starting to at last alarm the electorate—to rid itself of all responsibility in areas such as health and education. It is a backdoor method for the government to implement its fiscal consolidation strategy by cutting funds to the states and forcing states to increase their own state taxes and charges to pay for it.

The Costello tax has now been imposed in a number of states. In Victoria I think they were even considering giving it the name of the DOG tax. It is simply consistent, as I have said, with a whole range of other measures that this government is progressively introducing to rid itself of responsibility in these important national areas by devolving them to the states.

My own particular area of interest is regional Australia. I have been in public life now for 20 years, and I have not in 20 years seen a statement emanating from Canberra in respect of regional Australia such as the one that was issued by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, when he announced the complete abolition of the department of regional affairs. He, as I understand it, has retained his current title simply as an effort to save money on the stationery. As we all know, the Commonwealth government's active involvement in regional Australia has finished, and we have no less of an authority than Mr Sharp to go to for that.

In that press statement from Mr Sharp, the like of which I have never seen before—I know politicians are fond of saying, `This is the worst or the most terrible blow that has ever been struck,' or `This is the greatest lie ever told,' or so on; but, in this case, I would defy anybody to find a press statement issued from any minister in Canberra equal to it—Mr Sharp said this about the government's responsibility for regional Australia. In closing down the department, he said that there was no rationale or constitutional basis for the involvement of the Commonwealth government in regional development.

Just in case you thought that was a mighty slip of the word processor, in the following paragraph he went on to say—consistent with this piece of legislation—that regional development was the responsibility of the states and local government. The Commonwealth government, in one fell swoop after the election, simply washed its hands of regional Australia. That sent a chill down the spines of everybody living outside Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, I can assure you.

BREAK.PARA: The government were as good of their word, of course. They closed down all the REDO programs that had given so much benefit to regional centres. In fact, if you look at some of the interviews given by the mayors of those rural and regional communities, you will see that those programs were the only impetus that some of those communities had had for some significant time. This government closed down every single one of those commitments—except for the ones that were so far down the track they simply could not cut off the funding.

We have seen the closure of the Commonwealth's involvement in dental care services. I might add, for those interested in the history of this, that that was a commitment by the former Commonwealth government to fill an obvious gap that simply was not being filled by state governments. The impact on those people on low incomes—the people whom this government constantly professes to care about—will be very significant. The waiting lists—again, according to the Victorian government—for people who require this kind of dental care but cannot afford it will now blow out to something like seven or eight years, making the question of whether they finally get dental care a fairly academic one indeed, I would have thought.

The result of this bill passing through the Senate—as foretold by the Victorian Treasurer, not by me—will be that the effects will be borne by the taxpayers of Australia, in flagrant breach of the election commitment given by the coalition that there would be no increases in taxes. This bill in fact provides for them. I move:
At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate:

(b) notes that the Bill is part of Government policy to reduce the financial capacity of the States, contrary to Coalition election promises, which has led to increased State taxes;
(c) notes that the Bill is part of Government policy to reduce the financial capacity and resources of local government, contrary to election commitments; and

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats agree that the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 represents a little face‐saver for the Treasurer, Peter Costello. We also agree that it was a disastrous performance on his part at the Premiers Conference, his first Premiers Conference, although some would subscribe to the theory that there was a Howard-Costello good cop, bad cop routine operating—something we have seen since then as well.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a few issues, though, on which Premiers Jeff Kennett, Bob Carr and Rob Borbidge can agree. One of them was the unified sense of outrage that they felt—I think it was completely justifiable outrage—at Treasurer Costello's attempt to slap a $600 million sales tax bill on the states. I think Treasurer Costello thought it was very clever. In the end, he may have thought he was very clever because a deal was struck. The states volunteered to give $2 billion in grants over three years in preference to this continuing $600 million hole in their budgets. That was the threat: a continuing hole in their budgets.

The face‐saver for the Treasurer was this compromise initiative on sales tax on cars. This bill will eliminate the sales tax exemption on government motor vehicles which are used wholly or partly for private use as part of a negotiated remuneration package. We all vividly remember Treasurer Costello, hand on heart, saying, `I won't stand by and watch the tax system riddled and rorted.' And who was riddling and rorting it? Goodness me, he thought it was the state and local governments who were riddling and rorting the tax system. Of course it was a great performance. He never lets the facts get in the way of a good story.

He failed to distinguish between those motor vehicles which are used as part of a remuneration package and used in part for private use and those in permanent legitimate use, like those used by council work gangs, those used by welfare officers to visit homes and prisons and those used by building inspectors. The vehicles in these examples are used in pursuit of legitimate work. But not so according to the Treasurer, no, they are all riddling and rorting the system. Just as the Wright family seems to have gone into research and development with fictitious case studies, I suspect that the government might think that the Wrights are employed as fictitious senior public servants out there allegedly making a killing on the used‐car market.

We should draw attention to the way Treasurer Costello singles out those whom he wants to pursue for alleged riddling and rorting. He says, `Let's pursue these people who own these motor vehicles. But we will just turn a blind eye to business friends engaging in much worse tax evasion,' like the outrageous tax concession which many of his friends enjoy on infrastructure borrowing on urban roads, like the tax avoidance that many of his friends and associates enjoy through family companies or closely held private companies or like the token tax which is paid on interest and dividends paid overseas. It was not worth singling these out for action, was it? No. We just single out the states and local governments and we let the rest, these larger and much clearer cases of tax evasion, off scot‐free. That is very poor policy and it is also extremely hypocritical.

However, as we are acknowledging today, given those choices, the states have agreed to this compromise as part of the conference settlement. It could be argued that the states closed far too early and agreed to an appalling deal, especially when you add to this discussion what the states have suffered in terms of cost shifting as a result of the budget—they are to absorb all the responsibilities and get none of the revenue—and especially if you factor into the discussion the fact that federal government grants to the states have already fallen in real terms for most of the 1980s.

Grants fell from 17.8 per cent of Commonwealth outlays in 1984-85 to 12.6 per cent in 1994-95. Most of the fiscal tightening of the 1980s—the tightening which Paul Keating used to pay off his deficits and talk about his budget surpluses—actually happened at the state level. If you go into a Victorian school at the moment, if you go into a Queensland hospital or a New South Wales police station, you will see the results of that fiscal tightening and the emerging results of the effect of this government's first budget. You will see chronic underfunding, chronic underservicing and a chronic decline in standards. That is the cumulative effect of fiscal tightening through the 1980s, the Premiers Conference and the government's 1996 budget.

This government promised that states would not have their revenue cut. They have broken that promise, as previous speakers have said. This bill that we are being asked to pass today is part of a package of measures that put into place the breaking of that promise—the promise that Treasurer Costello and Prime Minister Howard made that taxes will not rise. It seems that you can conveniently make a distinction that if you pass on the effects of a tax then that does not count for your own actions.

The Democrats will support the ALP's amendment to the second reading motion. I hope the majority of the Senate does. We are supporting the bill, but in my remarks I just want to make it absolutely clear that we think this is a broken promise and a flawed approach. We think it is inconsistent and harmful when you realise that the costs are being passed on via state and local governments. That is the result of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is really a continuation of debate we have just had on the previous bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996, because it, too, deals with the outcome—the compromise—of the Premiers Conference held earlier this year. SPEECH.PARA: The third paragraph of the explanatory memorandum shows how generous the Commonwealth was, where it says:

At the 1996 Premiers Conference, the Commonwealth undertook to maintain the level of financial assistance grants to the States and Territories in real per capita terms in 1996-97 and to extend the real per capita guarantee until 1997-98.

If the Premiers thought the Premiers Conference was a bit of a mauling, I wonder what they really thought about the routing that was the 1996 budget. On top of the $1.55 billion worth of cuts in general purpose grants and the $200 million over four years in additional sales tax, the government clocked up a further $2.5 billion worth of cuts to specific purpose payments over the next four years. The cuts include cuts of $399 million to the successful Commonwealth Dental Service which is used by very low income earners. There were cuts to public housing funding of $344 million, legal aid funding of $104 million, urban and regional development of $415 million, vocational education and training of $63.4 million and the home and community care scheme of $88 million.

How could you be so proud of a budget which lays the knife so deeply and so widely into so many state programs and essential services used by struggling Australian families? I predict that the $4 billion worth of cuts to essential state services over four years are like a time bomb ticking under Mr Costello's budget. The reality is that the states have a very limited capacity to absorb these cuts because of the narrowness of their regressive tax base, the fact that they have already been cut substantially in the past and they are stretched to breaking point. Public hospitals and public schools have a non‐existent capacity to absorb further cuts of this nature.

On the matter of the need for dialogue—on the urgent need for a radical overhaul—on the state and federal imbalance when it comes to taxation, I have to say I agree with Premier Kennett. I do not say, like the Prime Minister says, that he should take a holiday.

I do not think I would agree with Premier Kennett on the outcome of the dialogue or on what should come out of an overhaul, because I believe that taxation should remain a federal responsibility. But I do acknowledge that the states need certainty in the funding base for the provision of the essential services that they provide. The double speak of this particular Premiers Conference shows just how useless their long sought guarantee of real per capita grants maintenance was. It was ignored.

The overhaul of federal and state responsibilities should look not just at funding but also at who is providing the service. The Democrats have long been of the view that the states should hand over to the Commonwealth full responsibility for running the public hospital system, for example, given that the Commonwealth is already picking up most of the tab through Medicare and other grants, and given that decent health standards are largely a national issue anyway.

This quality and difference in quality should not depend on the whim of the state premier or the state minister or the geography of where you live.

The states should be free to deliver the service in the most efficient way they see fit, so long as the service quality standards are met. In such a formulation of federalism, there are benefits for a federal government, a federal bureaucracy, a federal parliament, for the states and, most importantly, for the Australian people.

The double speak of this 1996 Premiers Conference—of calling something `fiscal contribution' when you are being bashed over the head and are having this money taken away from you, when you are coerced with `take this threat or this threat'—would disappear. It ought to disappear. Hidden spending cuts, flick passing budgetary problems—we need to sort these things out. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is the states house, and part of a senator's job is to raise matters of importance to the states and to defend their status within a federated Commonwealth. Today I wish to make some remarks about the national competition policy in that context, to reveal the extent to which states have been compromised in parts of the competition agreements they have signed. By lifting the veil on some of the workings of competition policy, I hope to make more people aware of what is happening and to stimulate debate about these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The national competition policy legislation was passed in June 1995. All the states have now passed complementary legislation to ensure a national phased‐in approach to competition policy. The first deadline, June 1996, has passed, requiring all jurisdictions to compile a legislative review timetable. The overarching body, the National Competition Council, has already produced its first report, as has the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, which administers the Trade Practices Act and the state and territory application acts. Provided all goes well, the nation has been told that the benefits of $23 billion will flow through the economy and the states will be eligible, in return for their cooperation with the new competition regime, for progressive tranches totalling $900 million by 1999‐2000.

It is appropriate to take stock of competition reform at this stage and assess how it is unfolding. The legislation was unique in that it tried to impose a common framework of operating principles on almost every sector of the economy. Its impact is comprehensive and pervasive, yet its effects are felt quite differently, depending on the market structure of a sector. This is why the Hilmer paradox can occur where reforms meant to increase competition may actually decrease competition. I have gone into this in detail before and refer those interested to my earlier speeches, including my National Press Club address.

Because of the wide range of reforms involved, I wish to confine my remarks to the legislative review section of the Hilmer reforms. Not enough time has been devoted to the ramifications of Hilmer on the fortunes of small business. State governments play a significant role as they begin their review process looking for anti‐competitive effects of laws and regulations.

The Queensland legislative review timetable identified restrictions on competition in 183 acts and 135 sets of regulations, orders, standards, codes and by‐laws. Several of these where state jurisdictions have similar laws will be looked at by a national body. The federal government's own legislative review schedule lists 98 separate reviews.

A methodology is developed so that the review bodies can determine whether the net effects of laws giving rise to an anti‐competitive effect are in the public interest. Governments, theoretically at least, then choose whether to act on the advice of the review bodies. Obviously, there is room for wide and subjective interpretation of what constitutes the public interest.

Because of the different market natures in our economy, some so‐called anti‐competitive effects are actually in the public interest. This is where governments step in and legislate specifically for exemptions to the competition rule. It is important to stress that the Hilmer framework allows for this. It provides for situations where exemptions may be necessary. Such flexibility is necessary if we are to have a sophisticated implementation of a very complex set of competition principles.

It is not a mature approach to point to exemptions as though the whole Hilmer framework will collapse as a result—it will not. It is not a mature approach to accuse a government if it makes an exemption of not being committed to competition policy reform. For example, the New South Wales government has used subsection 51(1) of the competition code to exempt the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games Amendment Act 1996. The New South Wales government has decided that it is in the public interest to exempt this act from the competition principles.

Let us look for a minute at the loci of power in the administration of competition policy. In the first instance, tremendous power is given to unelected people in the bodies tasked with reviewing these hundreds of pieces of legislation. It is these people who decide what the public good is and how to measure it. On top of this spectrum of review bodies are the state and federal competition policy units, usually from Treasury departments, coordinating the review process.

Climbing the apex further, there are the federal bodies: the National Competition Council, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and the Australian Competition Tribunal. They are all very powerful. At the top of the tree is the federal Treasurer, who has some unique powers, which I will go into later. So national competition policy has involved the establishment of a vast, complex and interlocking bureaucratic structure.

The way the process works is that, come review time, the business or interest groups affected—for example, taxidrivers or travel agents—have to front the review panel. They have already been deemed guilty of anti‐competitive behaviour and must establish a net public benefit to get out of gaol. This has obviously provided a huge opportunity for lawyers and lobbyists in the private and public sector. A recent report in the Financial Review states:
A major new market now being targeted by legal firms around Australia is advising local governments on how to avoid breaches of the Trade Practices Act.

In order to obtain a coherent and national approach to competition policy, the states signed competition code and principle agreements with the Commonwealth government. In doing so they effectively gave the Commonwealth ultimate power in the legislative review process. They surrendered the fate of hundreds of thousands of small businesses to the federal government, which acts on the advice of the ACCC and the NCC.

Firstly, they all agreed that the Commonwealth, through the NCC, could assess each state's progress towards competition reform. If states were not performing, then the promised financial tranches, the rewards, would not be forthcoming. These are due to start in 1997‐1998.

Secondly, the ACCC, a federal body, was given the power to grant temporary authorisation for anti‐competitive behaviour, irrespective of whether it occurs within state or federal jurisdictions. Thirdly, the states agreed that, where they made exceptions, they would legislate explicitly for them, referring to section 51 of the Trade Practices Act, as the New South Wales government did for the Olympic Organising Committee Amendment Act mentioned earlier. These three features of the competition regime show that the states have allowed long established business practices to fall within a jurisdiction they have not previously been subject to.

Many times I have been told by former government senior bureaucrats that the Commonwealth would not interfere with the states' decisions on granting exceptions. Indeed, a federal government would have to carefully weigh up the political costs of any proposed interference. Nevertheless, the states have signed away the ultimate decision making power on these issues to the Commonwealth, whether it uses that power or not.

This is the unique power of the federal Treasurer referred to earlier. It works like this: clause 2 of the conduct code agreement specifies the procedures for exceptions for the competition law and states:

Where legislation or a provision in legislation, is enacted or made in reliance upon section 51 of the competition law, the party responsible for the legislation will send written notice of legislation to the commission within 30 days of the legislation being enacted or made.
The National Competition Council's annual report explains:
The Commonwealth minister has the discretion to override the exception within four months of notification by tabling regulations in the Commonwealth parliament under section 51(1C) (f) of the TPA.
If the minister tables the regulations after four months, the minister may only override the exception upon tabling a report by the council.

This means that if a state government were to legislate, for example, to exempt taxi drivers from some deregulation in the public interest, the Treasurer may accept the NCC's advice to disallow the state government's exception.

In relation to the earlier example of the Sydney Olympics, the Treasurer has been given the power to move to veto the exception granted by the New South Wales government. When the states signed those competition agreements, they signed over the power to the Treasurer and the federal parliament.

The NCC has already expressed its dissatisfaction with the new ACT trading hours regime and forced the ACT to agree to a further review in two years time. The Queensland government, which has recently made a decision on trading hours also, will still have to have that decision reviewed under the competition principles. The National Competition Council may interfere as it has done in the ACT.

In Queensland, we have been witness to the extraordinary campaign by large retailers to get their way on trading hours. Is this a sign of things to come, where economic power and expensive advertising campaigns will be waged on various Hilmer issues? We have a situation where an unelected federal body has significant influence—even a hold—over a previously sovereign right of states to set trading hours. If the Commonwealth were to override a state exception, it is possible that the issue of compensation may arise if a business arrangement initially approved under state laws were stopped in its tracks by Commonwealth regulation.

To summarise, each state government is overseeing the review of hundreds of pieces of legislation which they have already identified as containing potentially anti‐competitive restrictions. Where the state governments legislate for exceptions under subsection 51(1), they are also subject effectively to the veto of the Commonwealth parliament.

The states have handed over the ultimate sanction to the Commonwealth. The fate of taxi drivers in Sydney, chiropractors in Perth, liquor outlets in Brisbane, pharmacists in Dubbo, architects in Melbourne, and so on, rests with the federal Treasurer or—if the authorisation route is taken—with the unelected ACCC.

It is worth pointing out that many industries may view the ACCC authorisation process as a last resort, preferring instead to obtain exceptions from state governments. Either way, the states have made Canberra the ultimate locus of power. Even if the Treasurer were never to use his power, its presence can act as a powerful deterrent to ensure states govern state matters according to the wishes of the NCC, the ACCC and the Treasury.

I am not just talking about the more topical exceptions such as wheat and sugar export marketing or newsagents and pharmacies. The states will have to use the exception process for many obvious reasons: to keep the handling and storage of explosives regulated; to keep environmental controls on development and industry; to restrict gaming machines to specified outlets; to prevent SP bookmaking and so on.

I wonder also whether religious and charitable organisations are aware that they can no longer take their special treatment under several laws for granted. An example is retirement villages dealing in second‐hand goods and hawker laws. Big business and industries such as sugar and wheat may be able to afford multimillion dollar review processes, but what about everyone else, including the St Vincent de Paul Society and Lifeline?

Local government is concerned that rates will have to be raised to meet higher taxation demands from corporatising their services. Concerns have also been raised in recent times by doctors, hospitals and universities about the impact of the Hilmer reforms. The states will be sending container loads of documents down to the ACCC and the NCC to be verified and examined, or seeking authorisation.

I do not think many people have yet realised how pervasive the new competition regime is, nor how technically powerful the federal government has become in determining the fate of so many micro businesses. It maybe that this power will be tested in the courts. After all, the Commonwealth does not have the constitutional power to legislate in the non‐incorporated areas of business. Yet the states have apparently willingly given up these powers. We can look forward to more legal wrangling, I am sure.

I would like to make one further point in relation to the exemption process. State exemptions made by regulation and not through a primary act are non-renewable and only effective for two years. Thereafter, authorisation must be sought from the ACCC with appeal rights to the competition tribunal, unless the state passes primary legislation, still subject to the Commonwealth's overriding powers.

Lest I be misunderstood, let me make it plain that I have no troubles with the objectives of the national competition policy. Of course we need more competition, efficiency and productivity. There are likely to be significant benefits but the unintended side effects of such a massive undertaking need to be recognised and debated. Many industries, state and local governments are still on the learning curve when it comes to the Hilmer reforms. It is a very difficult job to put the whole process in perspective.

We have reached the stage now where it is pertinent to throw three questions into the public arena. Did the states realise that they were handing over such significant and far-reaching powers to the Commonwealth? Is the competition regime constitutionally valid? Are the Australian people happy for the Commonwealth to have the powers to veto state decisions on everything from taxi drivers to trading hours?

SPEECH.PARA: This bill implements the agreed outcome for the 1996 Premiers Conference held in June this year. The bill provides for the payment of general revenue assistance to the states and territories of $16.3 billion in 1996-97 and thus represents a very significant portion of total funds available to states. States and territories can allocate the funds provided by the Commonwealth under this bill according to their own budgetary priorities.

As has been the case in recent years, the Commonwealth undertook to maintain financial assistance grants to the states in real per capita terms and to extend the guarantee until 1998-99. The bill also provides special revenue assistance of $481 million in the form of $428 million in Medicare guaranteed payments in New South Wales and Victoria and $10 million in special financial assistance to the Northern Territory.

In addition, the bill provides the framework for government to provide competition payments as was agreed at the April 1995 Council of Australian Governments meeting. These payments are subject to the states' complying with the conditions set out in the agreement.

Finally, the bill provides for the states and territories to make fiscal contributions by way of reductions from general revenue assistance, which were agreed at this year's Premiers Conference in recognition of the $10 billion budget deficit inherited by the Commonwealth government. In 1996-97, state fiscal contributions will amount to $619 million. These payments represent an important element of the government's fiscal consolidation program.

The bill does not require the states to make fiscal contributions, but simply permits a mechanism to make the payments by way of reductions from general revenue assistance. Some states have indicated preference for this method of payment. The Commonwealth has aimed to provide states and territories with maximum flexibility concerning the method of payment of the fiscal contribution. Other possible payment methods are direct payment to the Commonwealth or reduction in funding provided under specific purpose grants.

In summary, the bill provides certainty of funding for the states and territories, a framework implementing the competition payments, which were a feature of the national competition policy agreement, and flexibility for the payment of states' fiscal contribution. The opposition and the Democrats have proposed a second reading amendment, so I do not know whether they have been able to reach a consolidated amendment. I can see no sign from the chamber that they have. We will be opposing those amendments.

The odd thing here is that the measures set out in this bill were agreed by state premiers at the Premiers Conference. Given that the states themselves agreed to the measures set out in the bill, the government cannot see how it could possibly do otherwise than oppose these proposed amendments. As I said, we have noted the contributions made by members of the Senate. We do not agree with many of the comments which have been made. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has some major concerns with the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill and, to reflect those concerns, will be moving amendments at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is important as it forms the basis of this government's funding in both primary and secondary education. As such, it is very significant legislation in that it provides $14 billion in direct Commonwealth funding for schooling over the next four years. But the bill does not just deal with a great amount of money; it also makes some fundamental changes to the basis on which the Commonwealth funds government and non‐government schools. One of our aims in this debate will be to rectify the deficiencies that these changes will create. Our amendments will go towards rectifying some of those deficiencies.

We are talking here of an area which has had major advances over the last decade, an area which has developed in such a way that there is greater equity, participation and access to the school system. We recognise that despite that, there is still some way to go, and that was recognised by both sides before the last election.

But we are concerned that these decisions have been taken in the dark without sufficient participation and involvement not just by young Australians of school age but also by their parents, teachers, state governments and non‐government organisations. None of these sectors have had adequate participation in a review process. The government is coming in with a set agenda, built out of prejudice and ideology, with no regard to what has happened in the past and moving without adequate review.

BREAK.PARA: The only area of review covered by this legislation was the McKinnon review, which basically recommended that the government go the other way and not this way. But we have a government that is blind and oblivious to the recommendations of that review, blind and oblivious to the experience in Australia over the last 13 years or so, but that is pursuing its own ideological agenda.

Obviously there are some aspects of this legislation with which we agree. The continuing involvement of the national government in direct school funding clearly comes into that category. However, we see other proposals as highly damaging, particularly to the government school sector, and more objectionable because that undermining of the government school sector will grow in effect over time.

Over recent months we have seen two characteristics: a high level of incompetence by relevant ministers; and a ballooning of outrageous claims by the government on its aims and achievements in this area. Given some of the most outrageous claims by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) on funding for schools since this bill first appeared, this debate for us in the opposition provides a useful opportunity to examine those claims in the light of the facts. I intend to do that extensively so that those who have an interest in this area, especially those involved in the schooling sector, can clearly understand that this legislation is an unambiguous negative, particularly for government schools.

Let us look at the background to the legislation. The Commonwealth does provide funding for schools both directly through legislation like this and its predecessors and indirectly through financial assistance grants to the states of which about 24 per cent is spent by the states on government schools and some two per cent on non‐government schools. During the 13 years of the previous Labor government, direct Commonwealth expenditure on schooling rose by some 58 per cent in real terms. Education was a high priority for Labor and of course not just school education.

This government would have us believe that it also plans to significantly increase resources for schools at a time of budget restraint in other portfolio areas. No‐one could disagree that that is a virtuous aim but the trouble for all those involved in education is that it is just not true. Answers to questions posed in Senate estimates committee hearings clearly show that the net impact of this government's decisions on direct school funding is $128 million over four years from 1996‐97 to 1999‐2000. It is an actual fall for government schools of some $87.5 million. By way of overall impact, $128 million is a far cry from the claims made by the minister of $1½ billion, $2.3 billion additional, four per cent real growth and so on—you can all take your pick. It is a bit like playing bingo, it varies from occasion to occasion and it varies with the intensity of the heat applied to the minister.

We have heard all of these varying claims from the government in relation to this bill. They cannot all be true, and the fact is that none of them is true. Where do they come from? They come from the fervid imagination of the schools minister, and they come from convoluted calculations to disguise the real impact of this bill on the education sector.

For instance, the $1.5 billion claim is arrived at by adding direct Commonwealth school funding with a notional amount of the financial assistance grants, FAGs, based on the proportion of these which states and territories generally spend on schools. The relevant figures are shown in the submission by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee in its consideration of the bill. By subtracting the 1996 total of direct and indirect grants for government and non-government schools from the same total for the year 2000, a figure of $1.424 billion—an apparent increase in Commonwealth funding for schools—appears.

PARA.BREAK: There are a couple of things wrong with that figure. The government can try to fool people in the broader debate; they can try to fool people through their communications in the media, but they cannot fool those involved in the education sector. They cannot fool the parents. They cannot fool the teaching profes sion as well. They cannot, for instance, fool those from the Australian Council of State School Organisations, who wrote to us today in urgent correspondence, asking us all to vote against this bill in its present form and to vote for amendments which will markedly change the thrust of this legislation.

BREAK.PARA: As I say, $1.424 billion—an apparent increase—is all achieved by smoke and mirrors. The trouble with these figures is that, in the first instance, the DEETYA table provides for indexation and other increases for enrolment and population growth. They are not real because they do not allow for comparison in real terms, in constant terms. Just as importantly, they are inflated in another way. They take no account at all for the $1.5 billion in cuts made to financial assistance grants to the states last June, with the government trying to argue an extraordinary position that schools—which account for one-quarter of FAGs expenditure—will somehow now be quarantined from that enormous cut made by the federal government to FAGs over the next three years.

Certainly you have not fooled the state officials. You have not fooled your state colleagues, Senator Kemp. Those who appeared before the Senate committee and looked at this bill indicated quite clearly that they believe the effects of your cuts in FAGs would be well and truly felt in school education.

As if that were not enough, these financial assistance grants figures are also inflated in another way. The deception continues. The deceivers, we know full well, are on the other side of the parliament. Those who have been deceived are the kids and the parents and the teachers across the country. From 1997-98, those FAGs figures will also include another $400 million annually by way of road funding, which previously had been separately identified. So the FAGs pool becomes even smaller. You can see then that these figures are significantly distorted, and they tell absolutely nothing of the real picture of the impact of this government's decisions on school funding.

So much for the $1.5 billion claim which, in true sense, should have been $1.424 billion. The government's rhetoric then became even wilder and more adventurous and more aggressive when it went up to some $2.3 billion in so-called additional expenditure on government schools. This is from a minister who is running around the country, blowing out these figures at whim and achieving some degree of publicity for it. How does he go from $1.424 billion—a false figure—to $1.5 billion to $2.3 billion? To do that, the government added up the additional funding for schools, including the mythical FAGs and supplementation dollars. It will not be all that long before we see how much money actually goes through to the school system and the government will be exposed for the distortions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Deceit.

—and the deceit that has been perpetrated on the public. Thanks, Senator Carr. You included the mythical FAGs and supplementation dollars for 1997, 1998, 1999 and 2000. This double, triple and quadruple counting produced a grand total of $2.29 billion. As I say, you may fool some, but you are not fooling the state government departments who have come to the Senate committee and given evidence before it. You have not fooled the public. You have not fooled the teachers and the parents, nor will you.

BREAK.PARA: The figures are just one part of the story. The deceit perpetrated through the blossoming figures is just one part of the story. What this government is also trying to hide is the agenda which deliberately shifts national responsibility from the federal government and basically dismembers it. It is an agenda which pushes so much resource from government schools to non-government schools. There has not been proper scrutiny; there has not been proper consultation; and there has not been proper review, because this government wants to shield from public scrutiny its failure to meet national responsibilities by its planned removal of the requirements, for instance, for non-government schools seeking to access federal funding.

The government wants to move from national requirements to a situation where governments and people rely on states and territories to set out the rules for the national government to provide funds on a national basis. It does not pretend that such provisions will be on anything like a standard basis across the country.

So you are going from a national standards system of providing funding for non-government schools to a state‐by‐state system relying on state based requirements, guidelines or maybe just a press statement at best. There is no review or assessment of the current system to highlight any problems other than the McKinnon review, which basically recommended that the government go in a different direction to that in which this government is going.

The fact is that the states and the territories have in place, at best, a patchy and in many ways inadequate requirement system for non-government school registration and operation. For example, only two governments impose their own minimum enrolment numbers, and only the Northern Territory government examines the likely impact of a proposed new non‐government school on existing schools in a particular area.

So, if these considerations are ignored, what we are likely to see is an uneconomic use of necessarily finite resources. What is the sense, for instance, in having four schools in a catchment area all one-quarter full? To what budgetary extent are we willing to fund choice in schooling in the name of which the government is marching down this path?

Over the last 10 years, for instance, non-government schools have been funded by the Commonwealth according to what was called the new schools policy. This policy gave parents a reasonable choice on the type of school to which they send their children, but it also provided choice as an overlay to the more fundamental need of universal access to a quality government school. Non-government schools continued to grow and to flourish during these years of operation of the new schools policy. Non-government schools, for instance, were required to meet a level of minimum enrolment numbers—which appear particularly generous in the light of what is going on now in places such as Victoria.

Having already closed some 300 schools and reduced teacher numbers by 8,000, the Kennett government is now seeking to force another 113 schools to close or merge. The reason? The reason flies totally in the face of the policy arguments put forward by this minister. Phil Gude, the Victorian Minister of Education, says a `broad curriculum is more likely to be achieved in schools with larger enrolments'. The targeted schools include 86 primary schools with fewer than 175 enrolments and 18 secondary schools with enrolments under 400 students. But the minister says that there is greater choice in broader curriculum to be achieved in schools with larger enrolments.

What this government is telling us is in contradiction to the Victorian government. They are telling us that the policy of the former government which required 50 students in a primary school and 140 students in a secondary school was too harsh. They want us to believe a situation exists where, as evidence to the committee in New South Wales indicated, a school with five students is capable of receiving Commonwealth funding under the government's proposals. If you can stretch resources to that extent, a lot of people will be missing out and freedom of choice will become quite a hollow bit of rhetoric.

We will move amendments to this legislation requiring non-government schools seeking Commonwealth funding to enrol 50 students in primary school, 20 in a rural area, 100 in junior secondary school, years 7 to 10, and 140 in full secondary school, years 7 to 12. Our amendments will also require non-government schools seeking to establish or to significantly change their operations to put their proposals before state based committees so that the impact of the proposal or the proposed changes can be examined in light of their impact on the existing policy.

As I have said, Professor Ken McKinnon reviewed this area before the election. He debunked quite clearly the very points which the government is using to justify its abolition of the policy, such as the notion that choice in education can be infinitely expanded and that the establishment of non-government schools in any circumstances automatically results in savings to the public purse. That is advice the government has before it. That is the advice the government seeks to reject in pursuance of ideological fixation. That is one aspect of our concern.

We acknowledge that the abolition of the new schools policy formed part of the coalition's pre-election policy announcements. But what was not explained, however, was how it would be funded. The funding arrangements are quite simple when you look at the evidence provided by the department to the committee. The growth of the non-government sector will be funded by the enrolment benchmark adjustment—a permanent mechanism for reduction of Commonwealth expenditure on government schools. This will mean that some $177 million will be taken from government schools over the next four years.

The rationale for this extraordinary attack on schools is the cost to the state. As a consequence, the government is introducing a benchmark based on the average cost of a student in the state school system of some $3,400 for each student. It is arguing that, for every student who shifts from the state to the non-government school sector, some $1,700 per capita will go to the non-government sector. But this is fundamentally flawed. Evidence before the committee indicated that it should have been the marginal cost of a student rather than the average cost that should have been taken into account.
I will not quote at length, but Mr Christopher Taggart, the Director of Management Accounting at the New South Wales Department of School Education, told the committee:
. . . the DEET analysis is substantially flawed.
He said:
. . . to take all the school system, including the administrative and executive structures of the schools as well as the state infrastructure . . . as being deleted or changed in anyway is nonsense.
So the basis of assessment here is flawed. It is a flaw which has been highlighted consistently by just about every state in the Commonwealth.

We know that what is driving the government in this particular area is an agenda which was revealed by the leaked minutes of a coalition Expenditure Review Committee meeting on 3 and 4 June 1991. On a page headed `Education: David Kemp' we find the following quote:
He noted that the Coalition sought to encourage students to move from government to non-government schools. . .
That is the agenda. No policy review, just an ideological fixation. It was also agreed at that committee meeting:
. . . that Dr Kemp would report back to the Committee on non-government schools—whether additional expenditure could be offset by reductions in grants to government schools and in untied grants.

That is what you are doing. You are shifting the money from the government school sector to the non-government school sector on the basis of a hollow benchmark and in pursuance of an ideological fixation.

We have another concern with this legislation: it exposes this government's fancy rhetoric about literacy goals, its commitment to young people and its commitment to those who are disadvantaged. What you are doing is lumping together the former equity programs which were aimed at very specific groups of educationally disadvantaged young people. You are putting them all into one program, blurring the focus of them and, indeed, undermining the national priority designed to make changes affecting all those students.

It remains to be seen whether the funds provided continue to deliver the types of outcomes for which the programs were originally designed. Once again, the Australian Council of State School Organisations are under no allusions about this move. They see it as something quite critical in diminishing the capacity to target the disadvantaged, as their letter to us of the last few days would indicate.

This legislation exposes the government's hollow rhetoric of its commitment in this area, but at the same time it is very dangerous in that it will undermine a system that has been developed consistently over the last 15 years or so—a system which has served and which can continue to serve Australia well. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there can be little doubt that the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996 represents a fundamental shift in the funding arrangements for Australian schools. The bill has far‐reaching consequences for the future delivery of primary and secondary schooling in Australia. As Senator Bolkus said, this bill is based on deceit. I have to correct something that Senator Bolkus said. The $2.3 billion which the government says is additional funding for schools over the next four years is in fact not FAGs money. As I understand, it is 90 per cent supplementation, indexation and new enrolments. For that you can read inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill is based on a deliberate misrepresentation of figures. It is a bill which the Senate is being asked to debate when it is very clear that absolutely no-one—not the minister, not the government, not the department—knows what the impact of this legislation will be. The government hails the bill as:

. . . fulfilling the government's commitments to promote excellence and achievement through the provision of quality education . . . The Bill fosters a partnership approach with states and territories which recognises both the constitutional responsibility of states and territories for education and the Commonwealth's role in guiding national directions and priorities.

It is hard to imagine anything further from the truth than this statement. Senators should ask: is this a bill which seeks to destroy the public education system? The answer is, yes. Is this a bill which seeks to shift students away from state schools and into the private school system? Once again, the answer is yes. Is this a bill which promotes the rapid and uncontrolled expansion of new and existing private schools and punishes students who remain in government schools by cutting their per capita funding? Will this debate reopen the old divisive state aid debate? The answer is most certainly yes. Will this bill allow the federal government to step away from its responsibilities for education? It is the same answer.

One of the most striking things about the Senate committee's report was the general lack of support for this bill. I think it must have been quite difficult for the committee to pad out this document. You will see from the quotes in it that most of them are from either the minister or the department.
Apart from a government ideologically bound to private education, who else came forward to support this bill? The Coordinating Committee of Jewish Day Schools said:
We would believe that any group in the community who wishes to operate a school and who meet appropriate criteria, should be permitted to do so.

This was the general tenor of submissions by the Australian Association of Christian Schools, the Anglican Schools Commission, the Christian parents controlled schools and the Lutheran schools. These groups support the bill, as you would expect them to do. It is already possible for these groups to operate schools. The vast majority of their schools receive Commonwealth subsidies—and some are very considerable subsidies. Others do not because they do not qualify under the current new schools policy.

This new schools policy, which has been in place since 1986, required schools to have minimum enrolments and to demonstrate that there would not be an adverse impact on neighbouring schools, both government and non-government. In other words, it provided for planned educational provision and an orderly means by which decisions can be made about the establishment of new schools and the proper accountability for funding them. The question this bill deals with is whether or not Commonwealth funding should be made available to those schools without any restriction or any consideration of the impact of such new schools on the neighbouring schools and whether or not the considerable extra per capita cost of providing this funding should come out of the budget for public schooling.

The National Catholic Education Commission said in its submission to the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee that the Commonwealth could and should still play a significant role in advocating commitment by state governments to general principles of planning. They said that cooperative and coordinated planning for new schools should be encouraged but only on the basis that such planning does not frustrate the reasonable demand for places in non-government schools. It says that the Commonwealth would need to be satisfied that adequate planning has been undertaken so as to ensure the viability of a proposed school prior to approving its recurrent funding.

The Catholic commission goes on to say that, as a minimum, the process of consultation would include proponents of a new school gaining access to demographic and planning data at the state and territory level and consultative meetings between two or more education providers or, from time to time, between all peak provider bodies. I would argue that this is a sensible approach to planning our schools in Australia.

I think it needs to be noted by the Senate that not one of the witnesses before the committee was prepared to argue that the mechanism for drawing that funding from the public school budget was either fair or appropriate. As we have come to expect, it is ideology which drives the coalition government to privatise that which should remain public and it is ideology which dictates that the cost of its generosity towards private schools should be met by an already under‐resourced system of government schools.

By the year 2000, on the government's own projections, it will cost the Commonwealth $195 million more a year to fund 94,000 extra students in private schools, at current rates of recurrent grants. At the same time, it will save less than $10 million a year on the 23,000 children who it expects to exit the state system.

This government has increased spending in real terms in very few areas in the budget and schools are no exception. The government will fund the $185 per annum shortfall in its budget bottom line with a very devious mechanism it calls the enrolment benchmark adjustment. This ingenious mathematical equation will deduct $305 million from state education budgets over four years.

I mentioned earlier that the EBA is a punitive measure. It is also cumulative in its effect. The lower the proportion of students in government schools the lower the per capita funding of those students. The Commonwealth recurrent grants to state schools currently average $406 per student. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs prepared a table which shows what would happen, using the enrolment benchmark adjustment, if the proportion of students in private schools rose from just under 30 per cent as it currently stands to 35 per cent. With 35 per cent of all students in private schools, the $406 Commonwealth grant to state school students drops to just $259.

At 40 per cent, that grant would drop to $105. If that proportion was to reach 50 per cent, the grant would in fact be a debt and the states would actually owe the Commonwealth $295 for each student in a state school. This would amount to a debt of $412 million per annum which the states would have to pay to the Commonwealth—and that is on top of the loss of recurrent grants which would amount to another $260 million each year.

I sincerely hope that the proportion of students in Australia in private schools does not reach 50 per cent, but these figures show just how ridiculous, punitive and ill‐ considered this so-called enrolment benchmark adjustment is. I hope the government is not serious about putting it into effect. The Democrats believe government responsibility in relation to education is about a lot more than promoting choice. Choice is important, yes, but it is not and should not be the first priority of government or the goal to which all others must become subservient.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity on the adjournment debate to pay tribute to Dame Joan Hammond, who died today at the age of 84. Dame Joan was born in Christchurch, New Zealand, and educated at the Presbyterian Ladies College in Pymble, New South Wales. She studied at the Sydney Conservatorium, training initially as a violinist, but concentrating on singing following an arm injury. She made her debut as a soprano in 1931, her stage debut in Sydney in 1932, her operatic debut in Vienna in 1936, her concert debut in London in 1938 and her first world concert tour and concert tour of Australia in 1946.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Joan sang in the world's major opera houses and with the world's major organisations, including Covent Garden, Sadler's Wells, the Netherlands Opera, Liceo Barcelona, the Vienna State Opera, the Bolshoi in Moscow—she was the first Australian to sing there—the Kirov in Leningrad, the New York City Centre and the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust, the forerunner of the Australian Opera, until illness forced her retirement in 1965.

Renowned for her warm portrayals of Puccini heroines, Dame Joan sold more than one million copies of her recording `Oh, my beloved father'. She was the first known classical artist to receive a gold disc for sales of an aria. After retiring she was artistic director of the Victorian Opera Company from 1971 to 1976 and taught singing from 1975 to 1993 at the Victorian College of the Arts, where she was head of vocal studies, and the University of Melbourne.

Also a talented golfer, Dame Joan won the New South Wales junior golf championship in 1929 and the state title in 1932, 1934 and 1935, and was three times runner-up in the Australian amateur title. She was a sports writer for the Sydney Daily Telegraph and a member of the Royal Sydney Golf Club, the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, the Barwon Heads Golf Club and the Royal Motor Yacht Club, Dorset, England.

Dame Joan won the Sir Charles Santley award from the Worshipful Company of Musicians, London, in 1970, when she was also named musician of the year. She won the Lifetime Achievement Award from the Green Room Awards Association in 1988 and the Lifetime Achievement Award for excellence in recording from the Australasian Sound Recording Association in 1994. She published her autobiography, A voice, a life, in 1970.

Dame Joan Hammond's name will always be synonymous with the highest levels of opera in Australia and, indeed, on the international stage. She was someone of whom we should be all be very proud, not only as Australians but as lovers of song. She was obviously a magnificent all‐rounder. She always regarded Australia as her home. She retired here and contributed a great deal to the community over the last 30 years of her life once she had retired, I suspect somewhat prematurely, from the world of opera.

Her name was always one that was very well regarded at the highest levels. Certainly when I was growing up the name of Joan Hammond was a very famous one and I am sure it has remained so ever since. We can only marvel at the quality of her voice, which is still available to us on many recordings and CDs. I think it is a matter of regret that she has passed away. I would simply like it noted today that we pay tribute to the life and passing of Dame Joan Hammond.
