SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I will speak about secrecy which hopefully will gather a lot of attention. Governments in particular are often overwhelmed by numbers, financial matters and budgets. But if you ask people about politics, they do not respond with remarks about economics; they respond with how they feel about people, about politicians and their character—in other words, about accountability. `Secrecy' is the opposite of `accountability'. This evening I will speak on Western Australia where I have done a lot of work on this matter with the Commission on Government, but I believe that my remarks are apposite to Australia as a whole.

PARA.BREAK: The Australian Democrats support the recommendations of the WA Royal Commission 1992 and the Commission of Government Report No. 1. We support the promotion of the freedom of information regime as the governing legislation for determining when information held by the government should be disclosed. We support the enactment of privacy legislation to address specific privacy issues surrounding the storage, use and retrieval of personal data and data matching between government agencies. Also, we support the amendment to the Freedom of Information Act 1992 (WA) to make provi sion for the attachment of a public interest test to each of the exemption clauses in schedule 1 attached to that act.

SPEECH.PARA: The WA royal commission found that unnecessary secrecy surrounded actions taken by the government into some of the events into which the commission inquired. The government was found to have used official secrecy to keep the public deliberately uninformed. Openness in government is an indispensable prerequisite of accountability to the public. It is a democratic imperative. The right to vote is without substance, unless it is based on adequate information. If government truly is to be government for the people, if the public is to be able to participate in government and experience its benefits, the public must be properly informed about government and its affairs. Open government does not hold for all purposes and in all circumstances—but it should be the norm, and secrecy should be the exception. Information is the key to accountability in government.

Public access to government information was seriously hampered in Western Australia until, in accordance with the recommendations of the royal commission, freedom of information legislation was enacted in Western Australia in 1992. While this has considerably improved public access to information in government documents, albeit often with great resistance by bureaucrats and ministers—and I guess there should be echoes of this in the Commonwealth—information freedom is still hampered by extensive secrecy laws in state legislation.

This freedom of information legislation confers upon people a legally enforceable right of access to information held by agencies of both state and local government. The right of access to documents is qualified by specific exemptions, including the exemption of certain agencies. Additionally, the right relates to documents rather than information.

The WA royal commission in its inquiries also recommended that the range of exemption documents under the freedom of information legislation should be confined to a minimum. This recommendation was revisited by the Commission on Government inquiry into the secrecy laws of the state. I should say that in Western Australia there are over 100 acts with specific secrecy provisions which specifically avoid the freedom of information laws.

The Commission on Government made a number of recommendations on freedom of information. Recommendation No. 5 states that there should be a public interest test to each of the exemption clauses in schedule 1. Recommendation 5.2 states that the Freedom of Information Act should be amended to specifically empower the Information Commissioner to formulate guidelines designed to assist agencies on how to apply that public interest test. Recommendation 7 states that, prior to any enactments which purport to override or restrict the provisions of acts, there be a process of public consultation followed by a public report into the outcome by the minister administering the act.

In 1986 the Law Reform Commission of Western Australia recommended that administrative decision makers should, as a rule, be obliged to give reasons for decisions to persons sufficiently affected by those decisions. Again, in 1992 the WA royal commission recommended that an administrative decisions act be enacted as a matter of urgency in accordance with the 1986 report of the Law Reform Commission—and we are still pursuing that administrative appeals tribunal which we need. Now, 10 years later, this recommendation has still not been acted upon. There is no acceptable reason for the continued deprivation of the citizens of Western Australia of what should be accepted as a basic right inherent in our system of government. There is no justification for any further delay.

The official secrets of WA are in urgent need of systematic review. They are found in numerous statutes scattered throughout the law of the state. In their scope they go far beyond what is justifiable in protecting the legitimate interests of government and of those dealing with government. Even with the FOI legislation finally having been enacted, the ability of officials generally to promote open government has been seriously impaired by the unwarranted breadth of secrecy duties imposed upon them.

BREAK.PARA: Public servants are subject to a duty of confidentiality. In addition to the sections of many statutes which impose specific secrecy obligations upon public servants, there are generalised provisions. Consequently, bureaucrats are extremely careful about breaching those and, as a further consequence, we have an uninformed public. The WA criminal code also provides a penalty for a general offence of unauthorised disclosure of information.

The key characteristics of the constraints placed on public servants by secrecy legislation in statutes in the Public Sector Management Act 1994 are the control they reserve to government over the public release of information, and the high level of protection they give to the interests of government and the cabinet executive itself. The interests of government and the cabinet executive, as the events into which the WA Inc. royal commission inquiry demonstrated, are not the same as the interests of the public; they are special and private interests and not public interests. The WA Inc. royal commission recommended that the Commission on Government review the secrecy laws of the state—and that is exactly what it did.

In 1995 the Commission on Government conducted its public inquiry into secrecy laws in Western Australia. The WA Information Commissioner, Bronwyn Keighley-Gerardy, in her submission to the commission expressed this common sentiment at the public hearings:

Secrecy in the public sector is a tradition inherited from a constitutional monarchy and it has evolved as part of the entrenched culture of public administration. It is reinforced by the enactment of secrecy provisions in legislation. In spite of the spirit of openness which is embodied in the concept of FOI . . . existing practices in public sector agencies lean towards secrecy. That is, the public sector has a culture of secrecy rather than a culture of openness.

For some purposes, official secrecy has a necessary and proper place in the scheme of government. The exemption provisions of the FOI legislation are indicative of the situations in which this can be so. What needs to be emphasised, however, is that it is only the protection of most important public and private interests which can justify official secrecy.

The COG, in its final report on secrecy in the laws of WA, made a number of recommendations on official secrecy. Recommendation 12 covered a code of ethics. Recommendation 12(2) covered chief executive officers and chief employees of public sector bodies to be responsible for specifying classes of information that should be protected. Recommendation 12(3) made them responsible for publishing such classifications. Recommendation 12(4) made recommendations for it to be made available to the public.

If responsible government is to have substance in Western Australia, the constitutional role of responsibility must be discharged and seen to be discharged. The processes of parliament must accommodate this need. Accountability can only be exacted where those whose responsibility it is to call government to account are themselves possessed of, or are able to obtain, the information necessary to make considered judgments. Information is the key to accountability. Given parliament's role as a primary accountability agent of the public, accurate information is essential. Without information, the role and effectiveness of parliament can be neutralised.

The WA Inc. royal commission, during its inquiry, was particularly concerned with enhancing parliament's role as the gatherer of information about government and as the public's informant. The royal commission made three principal recommendations which ought to be in place if parliament is to effectively undertake this role. First, parliament should have optimal access to information of and about government. This requirement has a number of implications. It requires that both the obligations of the agencies of government and the hierarchy of parliament itself be so tailored that information can be obtained in a comprehensive and systematic fashion and that information not be withheld without full justification.

PARA.BREAK: The reforms introduced by the Financial Administration Audit Act 1985 (WA) have improved materially the information supplied to parliament by way of annual reports from public service departments and statutory authorities. However, parliament's own proce dures, and in particular question time and the committee system—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, the time for your contribution has concluded.
—I ask leave of the Senate to incorporate the remainder of my remarks and the footnotes to my remarks in Hansard .

BREAK.PARA: Leave granted.

However, Parliament's own procedures, and in particular, question time and the committee system are not constituted and practised in ways that bring the Executive fully under the scrutiny of Parliament.

Given the complexity and diversity of the operations of government, it is no longer adequate for Parliament to rely upon ad hoc measures when inquiring into the conduct of government. Steps have been taken in recent years to establish standing committees of Parliament to review aspects of executive accountability. If Parliament is to have any realistic prospect of bringing the Executive under adequate scrutiny, it must systematise its role. Committees are the most suitable means for achieving this purpose.
Second, if Parliament is to perform its role of scrutiny, it must know with relative certainty to whom it properly can turn to provide and/or hold responsible for the information it requires.

The principle of ministerial responsibility, as traditionally understood, contains an element of fiction. That is, the Minister is required to provide information to parliament in question time, about any matter within the reach of his or her portfolio responsibility. The minister will often have no prior knowledge of, or involvement in, the matter and furthermore, could not reasonably or realistically be expected to be responsible for it.

The WA Inc. Royal Commission made recommendations that a more realistic approach be taken on the obligation of the various arms of government to satisfy Parliament's information needs. Parliamentary committees in particular must be entitled as of right to exact information, from responsible officers of government, where matters fall within their spheres of actual responsibility. The actual manner in which government is being conducted and the actual responsibilities discharged by officials, and not an inflexible principle of ministerial responsibility, should ordain who is the appropriate officer from whom information can properly be sought by Parliament and, importantly, what information can appropriately be sought from that official.
Thirdly, if parliament is to discharge its constitutional responsibility it must be provided with:
. the resources and facilities necessary to pursue the inquiries it is entitled to make;
. the support and research capacity to inform its inquiries and to examine and evaluate the information it obtains from whatever source; and
. it must have the capability to effectively communicate its views to the public.
The COG in its Final Report on the Secrecy Laws of WA made a number of recommendations which address the issues raised by the Royal Commission.
Recommendation 14
The federal system of cabinet record keeping should be introduced in WA. In particular, cabinet minutes should be kept recording the collective decisions reached.
Cabinet notebooks should also be kept which record the individual contributions of ministers.
Recommendation 15
The position of Parliamentary Secretary to the Cabinet should be abolished and a position of Cabinet Secretary be created.

The duties of Cabinet Secretary should be set out specifically in Cabinet Handbook and include the accurate record keeping of the cabinet records, the proper access to the records and the provision of advice to the cabinet on procedural implications relating to matters before cabinet.
Recommendation 16
1. A cabinet register should be created and made available for public inspection after a cabinet meeting. The register should be maintained by the Cabinet Secretary and should reveal:

PARA.TAB: (a) the names of those who attend the cabinet meeting;
(b) a brief description of each cabinet decision;
(c) the quantum of any public funds thereby committed; and
(d) the minister responsible for implementation.

BREAK.PARA: 2. The Premier should have the discretion to exempt decisions from disclosure if he or she considers it to be in the public interest to do so.
3. The exemption period should be limited to a period of two years from the date of exemption or automatically cease upon the implementation of the decision.
4. The extension of the exemption period should not be possible.
Recommendation 17

1. The Freedom of Information Act 1992 is reviewed in accordance with s.113, the cabinet and Executive Council exemption (Schedule 1 cl.1) should be thoroughly examined. In examining this exemption, the following must be considered:
(a) the scope of the exemption and whether it is drafted too widely bearing in mind that only those documents, the disclosure of which are likely to undermine the unity of cabinet, should be exempt;
(b) whether any of the subclauses are superfluous and duplicate the protection found in other provisions.
2. Schedule 1 clause 1 of the Freedom of Information Act 1992 should be amended to provide that official publication decisions in the cabinet decisions register will not be caught by the exemption.
3. Schedule 1 clause 1 of the Freedom of Information Act 1992 should be amended to exempt specifically cabinet notebooks but only for a period of ten years.
Recommendation 20
Ministers, when taking office, should be bound by a statutory obligation to make an oath of accountability to the people of Western Australia.
Commercial Confidentiality
Commercial secrecy is where a person or business entity supplies commercial information to a governmental agency because:
. it is obliged by law to do so,
. because disclosure is necessary for the provision of a service, or;
. because it is seeking the advice or assistance of government in furthering its own private interests.

To the extent that a claim to commercial secrecy is justifiable at all, it is limited to the protection of the legitimate interests of the supplier of information. Where such a claim can properly be made against government, it is the responsibility of government to respect and uphold the supplier's interests.

The object of commercial secrecy is to prevent the public being informed of those activities. A major function of commercial secrecy is to protect the economic value of information which has value because it is kept secret.

Commercial secrecy in the public arena can have only one or other of two related justifications. The first is to secure an economic advantage to the public. The second is to safeguard against economic prejudice to the public.

Translating these justifications into principles which should guide the determination as to when secrecy legitimately can be claimed, the Australian Democrats consider the propositions contained in the usual commercial and business information exemptions to the FOI legislation provide an appropriate guide.

Governments consistently and persistently use commercial confidentiality to hide matters that should not be hidden, to conceal deals and arrangements that should be exposed, and to protect special, private and often improper relationships from public scrutiny and accountability.

I am going to speak about secrecy. Governments in particular are often overwhelmed by numbers, financial matters and budgets. But if you ask people about politics they do not respond with remarks about economics—they respond with how they feel about people, politicians, their character. In other words about accountability. And secrecy is the opposite to accountability.

(2) Can an iron-clad assurance be given to the Australian people that the virus will not affect people or native wildlife.
